container.heading: Video Lottery Facility Minimum Internal Control Standards

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.

“Bill validator” means an element of a video lottery terminal designed and configured to accept any combination of currency, gaming tickets, promotional play instruments, or other instruments authorized by the Commission for activating credits on a video lottery terminal.
“Cash” means currency and coin.
“Cash equivalent” means a:
Certified check, cashier’s check, treasurer’s check, travelers check, or money order that is:
Payable to the facility operator, "bearer", or "cash";
Drawn for a specific amount;
Currently dated not postdated;
Payable on demand; and
Without an endorsement; and
Certified check, cashier’s check, treasurer’s check, or money order that is:
Made payable to the presenting player;
Drawn for a specific amount;
Currently dated not postdated;
Payable on demand;
Endorsed by the presenting player; and
Without an endorsement other than that of the presenting player.

“Cash storage box” means a secure tamper resistant container in a bill validator into which currency, gaming tickets, promotional play instruments, or other instruments authorized by the Commission for activating credits on a video lottery terminal are deposited.
“Cashable credit” means a credit on a video lottery terminal which activates play and is convertible to cash at the conclusion of play.
Complimentary Services.
“Complimentary services” means any lodging, service, or item which:
Is offered by a facility operator directly or indirectly to a player at no cost or at a reduced cost; and
Is not generally available to the public.
“Complimentary services” does not include:
Noncashable credits issued to a player as part of a player incentive or reward program; and
Lodging available to the public through convention or government rates.

“Customer deposit account” means a player-specific account established in a facility operator’s cashiers’ cage accountability into which a player may deposit cash or funds accepted by means of personal check, wire transfer, cash equivalent, or other negotiable instrument.

“Gaming ticket” means an instrument that upon insertion into a video lottery terminal bill validator entitles the player inserting the gaming ticket to credits on a video lottery terminal corresponding to the amount printed on the gaming ticket.

“Gaming ticket system” means the collective hardware, software, communications technology, and other ancillary equipment owned or leased by a facility operator to facilitate the issuance or redemption of a gaming ticket.
“Noncashable credit” means a credit on a video lottery terminal which activates play but is not convertible to cash at the conclusion of play.
“Promotional play” means an award by a facility operator of noncashable credits on a video lottery terminal:
Directly or indirectly to a player; and
With or without regard to the:
Identity of the player; or
Player’s level of gaming activity.

“Promotional play system” means the collective hardware, software, communications technology and other ancillary equipment owned or leased by a facility operator to facilitate the award of promotional play at a video lottery terminal or table game by means of a:
Promotional play instrument; or
Download from the system to the video lottery terminal.
“Replacement check” means a personal check accepted by a facility operator in a counter check substitution, consolidation, or redemption transaction under Regulation .28 of this chapter.
“Signature”, for a facility employee or contractor, means:
At a minimum, the first initial, last name, and Commission license number, written by the facility employee or contractor; or

The unique identification code issued to the facility employee or contractor by the facility operator if the document to be signed is authorized by the Commission to be generated by a video lottery system and the method of signature is approved or required by the Commission.

“Video lottery system” means the collective hardware, software, communications technology, and other ancillary equipment owned or leased by a facility operator to collect, monitor, interpret, analyze, authorize, issue, redeem, report, and audit data with regard to activity at video lottery terminals, including, but not limited to, a:
Video lottery terminal data system;
Casino management system;
Gaming ticket system;
Promotional play system; and
Player tracking system.
“Wire transfer” means a transfer of funds by means of the Federal Reserve Bank wire system in accordance with the requirements of 12 C.F.R. 210.25 et seq.
A facility operator shall maintain complete, accurate, and legible records of all transactions pertaining to the revenues and expenses of a facility.
General ledger records shall be maintained on a double entry system of accounting with transactions recorded on a basis consistent with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States.
Subsidiary ledgers and records supporting general ledger records shall be prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States.
Subsidiary ledgers and records shall include, at a minimum, documents that:
Support the financial statements and all transactions impacting the financial statements including contracts or agreements with manufacturers, contractors, and management companies;
Pertain to proceeds including generation of, accounting for, and transmission into the State Lottery Fund;
Identify for each video lottery terminal and table game on a week-to-date, month-to-date, and year-to-date basis:
Handle;
Payout;
Win amount;
Win percentage; and
Average payout percentage;
Summarize the cost, by category of service, of complimentary services under Regulation .09 of this chapter;
Identify all costs and expenses associated with the operation of a facility;
Are prepared in compliance with the internal controls approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter; and
Relate to:
Loans and other amounts payable by a facility operator;
Player disputes including player complaint forms filed with the Commission under Regulation .47 of this chapter;
Negotiable instruments accepted, deposited, returned as uncollected or ultimately written-off by a facility operator under this chapter; and
Investments in property and equipment for the benefit of a facility.
A form or document required by this chapter, including stored data, shall have:
All information placed on the form or document recorded in ink or another permanent form; and
The title of the form or document and the name of the facility imprinted or preprinted on it.

If under this chapter multiple copies are required of a form or document, all copies shall have the name of the recipient receiving the copy preprinted on the bottom of the copy in order to differentiate between the copies.

If under this chapter a form or document is required to be accounted for by series number or copies of a form or document are required to be compared for agreement, the accounting department shall report exceptions in writing to the responsible department and facility’s internal audit department not later than 2 days after identification of the exception.
A facility operator may prepare more copies of a form or document than required by this chapter.

A facility operator shall develop a written description of its administrative and accounting procedures, including the system of internal controls over video lottery terminal and table game operations.
A facility operator’s internal controls are subject to review and approval under Regulation .05 of this chapter.
Internal controls shall, at a minimum, include:
Administrative controls and record keeping that document the authorization of transactions;
Accounting controls that provide reasonable assurance that:
Transactions or financial events which occur in connection with the operation of a video lottery terminal or table game are:
Executed in accordance with the facility operator’s authorization protocols;
Recorded to permit preparation of financial statements in conformance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States and the requirements of this chapter; and
Recorded to permit proper and timely reporting and calculation of proceeds and to maintain accountability for assets;
Access to assets is permitted only in accordance with the facility operator’s authorization protocols; and
The recorded accountability for assets is compared with existing assets at reasonable intervals and appropriate action is taken with regard to a discrepancy;
Procedures and controls for ensuring:
That a video lottery terminal accurately and timely communicates all required activities and financial details to the:
Central monitor and control system; and
Video lottery system;
That all functions, duties, and responsibilities are segregated and performed in accordance with sound financial practices by qualified personnel; and

Through the use of a surveillance and a security department, that the facility is secure at all times during normal operation and during any emergency due to malfunctioning equipment, loss of power, natural disaster, or any other cause;
Access controls which address, at a minimum:
Content of, and administrative responsibility over, the manual or computerized access control matrix governing employee access to restricted areas;
Issuance of a temporary access credential; and
Comprehensive key controls;
A record retention policy in accordance with Regulation .08 of this chapter;
Procedures and controls over the movement of cash and the count room;
Procedures and standards for conducting internal audits; and
Other procedures and controls the Commission may require to be included in a facility operator’s internal controls.
A facility operator shall make available a current version of its Commission-approved internal controls, in hard copy or through secure computer access, to:
All mandatory departments required under Regulation .10E(6) of this chapter; and
The Commission’s on-site office.

A facility operator shall maintain, in hard copy or electronic form, all superseded internal controls together with the written representations required under Regulation .05 of this chapter, for at least 5 years subsequent to the date the internal controls were superseded.
At least 60 days before video lottery terminal or table game operations are to commence, a facility operator shall submit its internal controls to the Commission for review and written approval.
The internal controls shall be accompanied by:

A certification by the facility operator’s chief executive officer or chief legal officer that the submitted internal controls conform to the requirements of State Government Article, Title 9, Subtitle 1A, Annotated Code of Maryland, and this chapter;
A certification by the facility operator’s director of finance that the submitted internal controls:
Establish a consistent overall system of internal controls;
Provide reasonable assurance that financial reporting conforms to generally accepted accounting principles in the United States; and
Conform to the requirements of State Government Article, Title 9, Subtitle 1A, Annotated Code of Maryland, and this chapter; and
An opinion letter by an independent certified public accountant expressing an opinion as to:
The effectiveness of the design of the submitted system of internal controls over financial reporting;
Whether the submitted system of internal controls conforms to the requirements of State Government Article, Title 9, Subtitle 1A, Annotated Code of Maryland, and this chapter; and

If applicable, whether a deviation from the requirements of State Government Article, Title 9, Subtitle 1A, Annotated Code of Maryland, or this chapter identified by the independent certified public accountant in the course of its review of the submitted system of internal controls is material.
A facility operator may not commence operations until its internal controls are approved in writing by the Commission.
If the Commission determines that a submitted internal control is deficient the:
Commission shall provide the facility operator with written notice of the deficiency; and
Facility operator shall revise the internal control as appropriate and resubmit to the Commission for review.
A facility operator may not implement a change or amendment in its approved internal controls without the prior written approval of the Commission.

A facility operator’s initial internal controls submission and a change or amendment to its approved internal controls shall be reviewed and approved in accordance with a process and time frame developed and implemented by the Commission.
The process developed by the Commission under §F of this regulation shall, at a minimum, require the facility operator to:
Submit a redlined copy of any section of the approved internal controls to be changed or amended with added text underlined and deleted text lined out;
Document on the redlined copy the date the Commission approved the section to be changed or amended and the date the revision was submitted to the Commission for review;
Submit a narrative explaining the reason for the change or amendment which includes the facility operator’s target date for implementation;
Submit the written representations required in §B(1) and (2) of this regulation with regard to the proposed change or amendment;
Maintain a log of all changes or amendments in approved internal controls which includes the initial approval date and the effective date of any change or amendment approved by the Commission; and
Mark each page of approved internal controls with the date on which it was approved by the Commission.
The Commission may require a facility operator to submit daily, weekly, monthly, quarterly, and annual reports of financial and statistical data.
Reports required under this regulation shall be in a form and submitted in accordance with a time frame specified by the Commission.
Unless otherwise specified by the Commission, reports to the Commission shall be signed by the:
Chief executive officer if the facility operator is a corporation;
General partner if the facility operator is a partnership;
Manager if the facility operator is a limited liability company;
Chief executive officer or functional equivalent if the facility operator is any other form of business association; or
Owner if the facility operator is a sole proprietorship.
A facility operator shall submit a report to the Commission on the due date specified by the Commission unless an extension has been approved in writing by the Commission.
The Commission may, on written notice to a facility operator, require an interim report to be submitted in a form and in accordance with a time frame specified by the Commission.

section.heading: Annual Audit and Other Regulatory Reports.

para.text: A facility operator shall cause its annual financial statements to be audited in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards by an independent certified public accountant.

The annual financial statements shall be prepared on a comparative basis for the current and prior fiscal year and present financial position and results of operations in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States.

The audited financial statements shall include a footnote reconciling and explaining any difference between the financial statements included in any report submitted to the Commission under Regulation .06 of this chapter and the audited financial statements.
A facility operator shall with regard to adjustments resulting from the annual audit:
Disclose to the Commission all adjustments whether or not recorded in the accounting records; and
Record the adjustment in the accounting records of the year to which the adjustment relates.
No later than 90 days after the end of its fiscal year, a facility operator shall submit to the Commission:
A copy of its audited financial statements; and
Any management letter or report prepared with regard to the financial statements by its independent certified public accountant.

A facility operator shall require the independent certified public accountant auditing its financial statements or other qualified entity approved by the Commission to render the following additional reports:
A report identifying:
Material weaknesses or significant deficiencies in the facility operator’s Commission-approved internal controls noted in the course of the examination of the financial statements; and
Recommendations as to how to eliminate each material weakness or significant deficiency identified; and

A report assessing the adequacy and effectiveness of the facility operator’s information technology security controls and system configurations with recommendations as to how to eliminate each material weakness or significant deficiency identified.
A facility operator shall prepare a written response to the reports required by §F of this regulation which includes details as to any corrective action taken.
No later than 120 days after the end of its fiscal year, a facility operator shall submit to the Commission a copy of:
The reports required under §F of this regulation;
The response required under §G of this regulation; and
Any other report on internal controls or other matters relative to its accounting or operating procedures rendered by its independent certified public accountant.
If a facility operator or any of its affiliates are publicly held, the facility operator shall submit to the Commission a copy of:
Any report required to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission including:
Form S-1;
Form 8-K;
Form 10-Q;
Form 10-K;
Proxy statement;
Information statement; and
Registration statement; and
Any other report required to be filed with a domestic or foreign securities regulatory agency.
A report required to be filed under §I of this regulation shall be submitted to the Commission no later than 10 days after the date of filing with the applicable agency.
A facility operator shall submit a written report to the Commission if an independent certified public accountant who is engaged as the principal accountant to audit its financial statements:
Resigns;
Is dismissed as the facility operator’s principal accountant; or
Is replaced by another independent certified public accountant as principal accountant.
A report required to be filed under §K of this regulation shall include:
The date of the resignation, dismissal, or new engagement;

Whether in connection with the audits of the 2 most recent years preceding a resignation, dismissal, or new engagement there were any disagreements, resolved or unresolved, with the former accountant on:
Accounting principles or practices;
Financial statement disclosure; or
Auditing scope or procedure;
The nature of any disagreement disclosed in §L(2) of this regulation;
Whether the principal accountant's report on the financial statements for either of the past 2 years contained an adverse opinion or disclaimer of opinion or was qualified;
The nature of any adverse opinion, disclaimer of opinion, or qualification; and

A letter from the former principal accountant addressed to the Commission stating whether the principal accountant concurs with the statements made by the facility operator in the report to the Commission submitted under this section.

A report required to be filed under §K of this regulation shall be submitted to the Commission no later than 10 days after the end of the month in which the resignation, dismissal, or new engagement occurred.

No later than 7 days after the date of filing with the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, a facility operator shall provide the Commission the Commission with access to each Suspicious Activity Report-Casino filed under 31 CFR §103.21.

A facility operator or a director, officer, employee, or agent of a facility operator who reports suspicious activity under 31 CFR §103.21 may not notify an individual involved in the suspicious activity that the suspicious activity has been reported.

No later than 7 days after the date of filing with the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, a facility operator shall provide the Commission with access to each Currency Transaction Report by Casino filed under 31 CFR §103.22.
At least 30 days before video lottery terminal operations are to commence, a facility operator shall submit to the Commission a copy of its compliance program required under 31 CFR §103.64.
On or before the effective date, a facility operator shall submit to the Commission any change or amendment to its compliance program required under 31 CFR §103.64.
Definition.
In this regulation, the following term has the meaning indicated.

Term Defined. “Books and records” means any document pertaining to, prepared in, or generated by a facility operator, without regard to the medium through which the record is generated or maintained, including all general ledger records, subsidiary records and ledgers, computer-generated data, forms, documents, internal audit reports and work papers, correspondence, and personnel records.
All original books and records shall be:
Prepared and maintained in a complete, accurate, and legible form;
Stored in a format that ensures readability, regardless of whether the technology or software that created or maintains it has become obsolete;
Retained in a secure location equipped with a fire notification system:
At the facility; or
An off-site location approved by the Commission under §G of this regulation for the express purpose of document storage;
Kept immediately available for inspection by the Commission during all hours of operation;
Organized and indexed in a manner designed to provide immediate accessibility to the Commission; and
Destroyed only after expiration of the minimum retention period required under this regulation.

The Commission may, on submission of a written request or alternate record retention schedule by a facility operator, authorize destruction prior to the expiration of the minimum retention period required under this regulation.

Unless a request for destruction or alternate record retention schedule is submitted in writing and approved in writing by the Commission, a facility operator shall retain indefinitely original books and records documenting:
Ownership of the facility;
Internally initiated investigations and due diligence;
Personnel matters;
Signature cards of current employees; and
Destruction of documents including:
The identity of the document;
Period of retention; and
Date of destruction.

Unless a request for destruction or alternate record retention schedule is submitted in writing and approved in writing by the Commission, a facility operator shall retain for a minimum of 5 years all original books and records not:
Identified for indefinite retention under §D of this regulation; or
Subject to an exemption under §F of this regulation.
Exceptions. The following exceptions apply to the retention period in §D of this regulation:
A minimum retention period of 4 years shall apply to documentation pertaining to cashiers’ cage transactions;
A minimum retention period of 3 years shall apply to:
Signature cards of terminated employees;
Insurance records relating to claims by players;
Surveillance and security department:
Employee duty logs;
Visitor logs;
Incident logs;
Recording logs; and
Equipment malfunction reports; and
Documentation pertaining to gaming tickets or promotional play instruments reported to the Commission as possibly counterfeit, altered, or tampered with;
A minimum retention period of 30 days shall apply to:
Cancelled promotional play instruments for which all reconciliations required by the facility operator’s approved internal controls have been conducted and resolved;
Voided gaming tickets; and
Gaming tickets redeemed at a location other than a video lottery terminal or ticket redemption unit; and
A minimum retention period of 7 days shall apply to gaming tickets redeemed at a video lottery terminal or ticket redemption unit.
On submission of a written request by the facility operator, the Commission may approve a location outside the facility to store original books and records.
A facility operator requesting to store original books and records outside the facility shall submit to the Commission:
A description of the proposed location, including details with regard to security and fire notification systems;
Details with regard to the ownership of the proposed storage facility; and
Procedures for Commission access to original books and records retained at the proposed location.
A facility operator may not store books and records outside the facility without the prior written approval of the Commission.

On submission of a written request by a facility operator, the Commission may approve a microfilm, microfiche, or other suitable media system for the copying and storage of original books and records.
A facility operator submitting a system for the copying and storage of original books and records shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Commission that the:
Processing, preservation, and maintenance methods to be utilized will make books and records readily available for review and reproduction;
Inspection and quality control methods to be utilized will ensure that when books and records are viewed or reproduced they will exhibit a high degree of legibility and readability;
Equipment necessary to readily locate, read, and reproduce books and records is available to the Commission at the facility or approved off-site storage location; and

Detailed index of all microfilmed, microfiched, or other stored data maintained and arranged to facilitate the immediate location of particular books and records is available to the Commission at the facility or approved off-site storage location.

A facility operator may not utilize a microfilm, microfiche, or other suitable media system for the copying and storage of original books and records without the prior written approval of the Commission.
A facility operator may utilize the services of a contractor for the destruction of books and records permitted to be destroyed under this regulation.

Nothing in this regulation shall be construed as relieving a facility operator of any obligation to prepare or maintain books and records required by any other federal, State, or local governmental entity.
Definition.

A facility operator shall be under the authority of the County Alcoholic Beverages Licensing Authority for the county in which the facility is located with regard to the sale to individuals of food and alcoholic beverages;
Except as provided in this section, a facility operator may not provide food or alcoholic beverages to individuals at no cost;

Food or alcoholic beverages offered by a facility operator for sale to individuals may be offered only at prices that are determined by the County Alcoholic Beverages Licensing Authority to be commensurate with the price of similar types of food and alcoholic beverages at restaurants in the county in which the facility is located; and

A facility operator may provide food at no cost to individuals to the same extent allowed under Article 2B, §12-106, Annotated Code of Maryland, for a person engaged in the sale or barter of spirituous, malt, or intoxicating liquors and licensed in Maryland.
A facility operator shall develop, maintain in writing, and implement adequate internal controls over the authorization and provision of complimentary services.

A facility operator shall at all times make available to the Commission the internal controls required under §C of this regulation but is not required to include them in the system of internal controls submitted to the Commission for approval under Regulation .05 of this chapter.
A facility operator shall collect and retain data pertaining to the cost of, and number of individuals provided with, each category of complimentary services.
Report.
A facility operator shall submit to the Commission a quarterly report summarizing complimentary services provided during the reporting period.
The report shall include year-to-date totals of complimentary services provided.
The report must be submitted:
On or before the 15th day of the month following the end of each quarter; or
At the request of the Commission.
The report required under §F of this regulation shall:
Separate complimentary services into the following categories:
Rooms;
Food and Beverage;
Travel;
Gifts:
Cash; and
Noncash; and
Other; and
Determine the cost of complimentary services provided to a player as follows:

Complimentary services offered by a facility operator in the normal course of business shall be reported at an amount based upon the full retail price normally charged for the service by the facility operator;

Complimentary services not offered for sale by the facility operator in the normal course of business but provided directly by the facility operator to the player shall be reported at an amount based upon the actual cost to the facility operator of providing the service;

Complimentary services provided directly or indirectly on behalf of a facility operator by a third party not related to the facility operator shall be reported at an amount based upon the actual cost to the facility operator of having the third party provide the service; and

Complimentary services provided directly or indirectly on behalf of a facility operator by a third party related to the facility operator shall be reported at an amount based upon the actual cost to the third party of providing the service.
A facility operator shall submit to the Commission a report identifying a player who, together with guests, received $5,000 or more in complimentary services within a period of 5 consecutive days.
The report required by §G of this regulation shall:
State the reason complimentary services were provided;
Include the player’s rating in the facility operator’s player rating system at the time the complimentary services were provided;
Disclose the total amount, including year-to-date totals, provided in complimentary services separated into the following categories:
Rooms;
Food and Beverage;
Travel;
Gifts:
Cash; and
Noncash; and
Other; and
Be submitted:
At least quarterly, by the 15th day of the month following the end of each quarter; or
At the request of the Commission.

For the purposes of this regulation, the title used to describe a department head is intended to indicate responsibility for the functions of the enumerated department and does not obligate the facility operator to the use of that particular title.
Subject to the requirements of this regulation, a facility operator shall tailor its table of organization to meet its needs and policies.

At least 30 days before video lottery terminal or table game operations are to commence, a facility operator shall submit to the Commission for review and written approval a table of organization depicting all direct and indirect reporting lines for:
The chief executive officer required under §E(5) of this regulation;
Mandatory departments required under §E(6) of this regulation;
The cashiers’ cage manager required under §M of this regulation;
Employees authorized to verify credit applications under Regulation .25 of this chapter; and
Employees authorized to extend credit or to approve credit limit increases under Regulation .24 of this chapter.
A facility operator may not commence operations until the table of organization submitted under §C of this regulation is approved in writing by the Commission.
A facility operator’s table of organization shall include:
A system of personnel and chain of command which permits management and supervisory personnel to be held accountable for actions or omissions within their areas of responsibility;
The segregation of incompatible functions, duties, and responsibilities so that no individual is in a position to both:
Commit an error or to perpetrate a fraud; and
Conceal the error or fraud in the normal course of the individual’s duties;
All functions, duties, and responsibilities of qualified personnel;
Areas of responsibility which are not so extensive as to be impractical for one individual to monitor;
A chief executive officer:
Based for employment purposes at the facility;
Licensed as a principal employee; and
Ultimately responsible for the daily conduct of all operations at the facility; and
The following mandatory departments and supervisors:
A surveillance department supervised by a director of surveillance:
Based for employment purposes at the facility;
Subject to the reporting requirements of §G of this regulation;
Licensed as a principal employee; and
Responsible for the surveillance of all aspects of video lottery terminal and table game operations;
An internal audit department supervised by a director of internal audit:
Based for employment purposes at the facility;
Subject to the reporting requirements of §G of this regulation;
Licensed as a principal employee; and

Responsible for assessing compliance with approved internal controls, applicable laws and regulations, the reliability of financial reporting, deterring and investigating fraud, and the safeguarding of assets;
An information technology department supervised by a director of information technology:
Based for employment purposes at the facility;
Licensed as a principal employee; and

Responsible for the quality, reliability, accuracy, and security of all video lottery systems and associated equipment and software utilized by the facility operator regardless of whether the data, software, or systems are located in or outside the facility;
A security department supervised by a director of security:
Based for employment purposes at the facility;
Licensed as a principal employee; and
Responsible for the overall security of the facility;
An accounting department supervised by a director of finance:
Based for employment purposes at the facility;
Licensed as a principal employee; and
Responsible for all accounting and finance functions including the control and supervision of the cashiers' cage, satellite cages, and count room; and
A gaming operations department supervised by a director of gaming operations:
Based for employment purposes at the facility;
Licensed as a principal employee; and
Responsible for the operation and conduct of gaming at video lottery terminals and table games.

Nothing in this regulation shall preclude a facility operator from establishing a video lottery terminals and table games department supervised by a director of video lottery terminal operations and a director of table games operation.

The director of surveillance and the director of internal audit required under §E(6) of this regulation shall be independent of the chief executive officer regarding matters of policy, purpose, responsibility, and authority and shall report directly to an:
Individual based for employment purposes at the facility with no incompatible functions; or
Audit committee of:
The facility operator; or
A Commission-authorized licensed affiliate of the facility operator.

The individual or audit committee to whom the director of surveillance and the director of internal audit report under §G of this regulation shall also control the hiring, termination, and salary of the director.
The director of surveillance and the director of internal audit may report to the chief executive officer with regard to daily operations.
Mandatory departments and the supervisors over them shall cooperate with, yet perform independently of, all other mandatory departments and supervisory positions.
A facility operator may designate more than one individual to serve jointly as the director of a mandatory department required by §E of this regulation.
A joint director of a mandatory department under §K of this regulation shall be:
Based for employment purposes at the facility; and
Individually and jointly accountable and responsible for the operation of the department.
A department that is not mandatory may operate under, or in conjunction with, a mandatory department where the table of organization is consistent with the requirements of §E of this regulation.
A facility operator’s cashiers’ cage manager shall be licensed as a principal employee.

Unless another principal employee required by this regulation is present at the facility, on any shift for which the cashiers’ cage manager is not present in the facility, the cashiers’ cage shift manager responsible for the cashiers’ cage shall be licensed as a principal employee.
A facility operator may not implement a change in the table of organization approved by the Commission under §D of this regulation without the prior written approval of the Commission.
A facility operator shall ensure that an individual employed at the facility is trained in the policies, procedures, and internal controls relevant to the individual’s function.
Vacancy. If there is a vacancy in the chief executive officer position or any mandatory department director position required by §E of this regulation, the following shall apply:
No later than 5 days after the date of a vacancy, a facility operator shall notify the Commission in writing of:
The vacant position;
The date on which the position will become or became vacant; and
The date on which the facility operator anticipates that the vacancy will be filled on a permanent basis;
No later than 30 days after the date of a vacancy, a facility operator shall fill the vacant position on a temporary basis;
No later than 120 days after the original date of the vacancy, a facility operator shall fill the vacant position on a permanent basis; and
No later than 5 days after filling a vacancy, a facility operator shall notify the Commission in writing of:
The vacant position filled;
The name of the individual designated to fill the position;
The date that the vacancy was filled; and
Whether the vacancy has been filled on a temporary or permanent basis.
A facility operator shall install in its facility a surveillance system that complies with the requirements of this regulation.
A facility operator’s surveillance system shall be reviewed and approved by the Commission under Regulation .12 of this chapter.
A facility operator’s surveillance system shall include:
Light sensitive cameras enabled by:
Lenses of sufficient magnification to read a video lottery terminal reel strip and credit meter;
Lighting which is continuous and of sufficient quality to produce clear video recordings and still pictures; and
360-degree pan, tilt, and zoom capability, without camera stops, configured to clandestinely monitor and record:
Play and transactions conducted at video lottery terminals;
Transactions conducted in the cashiers' cage and any satellite cage including the face of each individual transacting business with a cashier;
Transactions conducted at ticket redemption units, automated jackpot payout machines, and automated teller machines;
Activity in the count room;
Movement of cash and cash storage boxes within the facility;
Entrances and exits to the facility and the gaming floor;
Activities in all other restricted areas; and
Other areas and events designated by the Commission;
A monitor room located in the facility:
Staffed by employees of the facility operator’s surveillance department 24 hours per day; and
Equipped with:
A communication system capable of monitoring all security department communications;
Connections, direct or through a documented communication protocol with the security department, to all facility alarm systems;
A surveillance failure notification system that provides an audible, as well as a visual notification, of any failure in the surveillance system or the digital video recording media storage system;

An emergency power system, tested by the facility operator in the presence of the Commission at least once a year, which can be used to operate the surveillance system in the event of a power failure;
Computer terminals permitting event notification to, and read only access by authorized surveillance department employees to, the facility operator’s video lottery system;
An updated photo library, consisting of photographs that are no more than 5 years old, of all current employees of the facility;
A copy of the facility operator’s gaming floor plan required under COMAR 36.03.11.05;
A copy of the procedures addressing the evacuation of the facility in the event of fire or other emergency required under Regulation .14 of this chapter; and
Copies of the surveillance system contingency plans required under Regulation .12 of this chapter;
Digital video recording capability equipped to:
Superimpose the date and time on all monitoring and recording;
Identify and locate, through the use of a meter, counter, or other device or method, a particular event which was recorded;
Identify on video recording disks or other storage media the type of media player and software prerequisite to viewing the digital images; and
Be authenticated through use of an embedded video verification encryption code or watermark;
Audio recording capability in the count room that is:
Installed and disclosed to employees of the facility; and
Consistent with Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article, §§10-401—10-414, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
An access system which:
Controls:
Physical and logical access to the surveillance system; and
Physical access to the surveillance monitor room; and
Restricts access to the security administration capabilities of the system.
A facility operator shall configure its surveillance system to record all areas and transactions enumerated in §C(1)(c) of this regulation with a resolution of 4 common image format at a minimum of:
For a standard definition camera, 30 frames per second; or
For a high definition camera, 15 frames per second.

A facility operator may configure its surveillance system to record activity in areas of the facility not covered by §D of this regulation at a reduced frame rate with a resolution of 4 common image format, as follows:
Public areas shall be recorded at a minimum frame rate of 15 frames per second; and
Areas not accessible to the public shall be recorded at a minimum frame rate of 7.5 frames per second.
Except as provided in §G of this regulation, a facility operator shall retain surveillance recordings:
For a minimum of 7 days for transactions or events in the areas covered under §E of this regulation; and
For a minimum of 14 days for transactions or event in the areas covered under §D of this regulation.

Upon the request of the Commission or a law enforcement agency that has proper jurisdiction over the facility, a recording shall be retained and stored in accordance with the directives of the Commission or law enforcement agency pertaining to that recording.
Except as provided in this regulation, the surveillance system shall be under the exclusive control of the facility operator’s surveillance department.
A facility operator shall provide the Commission with timely and unfettered access to its surveillance monitor room, surveillance system, and all transmissions.
A facility operator shall timely comply with a request from the Commission to:
Use, as necessary, any monitor room in the facility;
Display on the monitors in its monitor room or in the Commission’s on-site monitor room any event capable of being captured by the surveillance system;
Relinquish control of a camera or monitor;
Discontinue monitoring a particular camera or recording activity captured by it;
Make a video recording or photograph of any event capable of being captured by the surveillance system; and
Restrict or deny access to a recording or photograph.
A surveillance system may not be remotely accessed from a location outside the surveillance monitor room without the prior written approval of the Commission.
An entrance to a surveillance monitor room may not be visible from the gaming floor.
At least 60 days before video lottery terminal or table game operations are to commence, a facility operator shall submit to the Commission for review and written approval:
A surveillance system meeting the requirements of Regulation .11 of this chapter including, at a minimum, details pertaining to:
Camera configuration inside and outside the facility;
Monitor room configuration;
Video recording format and configuration specifications;
Authentication of digital recordings, including Commission access to the system’s video verification encryption code or watermark;
Audio recording format; and
System access controls; and
Surveillance department operating procedures conforming to this regulation.
A facility operator may not commence operations until its surveillance system and surveillance department operating procedures are approved in writing by the Commission.
A facility operator’s surveillance department operating procedures shall, at a minimum, require:
Coverage of all areas and transactions enumerated in Regulation .11 of this chapter;
Contingency plans addressing:
Full and partial failure of the surveillance system including:
A contact list with telephone numbers for individuals required to be notified in the event of a failure; and
Facility closure protocols; and
Planned shutdown of the surveillance system;
A surveillance incident log:
Maintained by monitor room employees in:
A book with bound numbered pages that cannot be readily removed; or
An electronic format equipped with software that prevents modification of an entry after it has been initially entered into the system; and
Documenting the scheduled coverage in §C(1) of this regulation and all other nonroutine surveillance activity as follows:
Date and time surveillance is commenced;
Name and Commission license number of the individual initiating, performing, or supervising the surveillance;
Reason for the surveillance;
Whether the suspicious activity involves an alleged regulatory violation or criminal activity;
Name, if known, alias, or description of an individual being monitored;
Description of the activity in which the individual being monitored is engaged;
Reading on a meter, counter, or device that identifies the point on the video recording at which the event was recorded;
Time at which a video recording is commenced and terminated, if different than when surveillance is commenced or terminated;
Date and time surveillance is terminated;
Summary of the results of the surveillance; and
Description of the time, date, and cause of any equipment or camera malfunction which occurred during the conduct of surveillance;
A surveillance room entry log:
To be signed by an individual entering the surveillance monitor room who is not a surveillance department employee assigned to the monitor room’s work shift at the time of entry;
Maintained by monitor room employees in:
A book with bound numbered pages that cannot be readily removed; or
An electronic format equipped with software that prevents modification of an entry after it has been initially entered into the system; and
Documenting the following:
Date and time of entering the monitor room;
The entering individual's name and department or affiliation;
The reason for entering the monitor room;
The name of the individual authorizing the individual's entry into the monitor room; and
The date and time of exiting the monitor room;
That surveillance monitor room employees notify:
Security department supervisory personnel within 5 minutes of an incident of equipment failure affecting coverage of the facility; and
The Commission within 30 minutes of an incident of equipment failure affecting coverage of the facility citing:
Date and time;
Cause of the malfunction; and
Time the facility operator’s security department was notified of the malfunction;
That the facility operator confirm in writing a notice given verbally to the Commission under §C(5) of this regulation; and
That, on a daily basis, the facility operator synchronize the date and time on the surveillance system to the date and time on the central monitor and control system and its video lottery system.

A facility operator may not implement a change or amendment in its surveillance system or surveillance department operating procedures approved by the Commission under §B of this regulation without the prior written approval of the Commission.
Surveillance department employees shall be reasonably segregated and independent of all other departments at the facility.
A surveillance department employee may not transfer to any other department in the facility without the prior written approval of the Commission.

At least 60 days before video lottery terminal or table game operations are to commence, a facility operator shall submit its surveillance department minimum staffing plan to the Commission for review and written approval.
A facility operator may not commence operations until its surveillance department minimum staffing plan is approved in writing by the Commission.
A surveillance department minimum staffing plan shall assess, on a per-shift basis, the minimum number of on duty surveillance department employees necessary to:
Provide adequate and effective surveillance of all activities in and outside the facility;
Ensure the physical safety of employees of and invitees to the facility;
Comply with all applicable laws and regulations including Commission-approved internal controls and operating procedures;
Monitor the facility to ensure that the following individuals are identified, prohibited from entering the facility, and, if necessary, immediately removed from the facility:
An intoxicated individual;
An individual who is mandatorily excluded in accordance with State Government Article, §9-1A-24(d), Annotated Code of Maryland; and
An individual who is voluntarily excluded in accordance State Government Article, §9-1A-24(e), Annotated Code of Maryland; and

Monitor the gaming floor to ensure that an individual under the age of 21 years is identified, prohibited from accessing the gaming floor in accordance with State Government Article, §9-1A-24(c), Annotated Code of Maryland, and, if necessary, immediately removed from the gaming floor.
A facility operator’s proposed surveillance department minimum staffing plan shall consider:
Square footage and layout of the facility;
Number and configuration of video lottery terminals and table games;
Use of fixed and roving security posts;
Activity level on a per-shift basis and identify it as slow, normal, or peak;
Department supervisory needs; and
A limit of one employee per monitor station.

A facility operator may not implement a change or amendment in the surveillance department minimum staffing plan approved by the Commission under §B of this regulation without the prior written approval of the Commission.

At least 60 days before video lottery or table game operations are to commence, a facility operator shall submit to the Commission for review and written approval its security department operating procedures.
A facility operator may not commence operations until its security department operating procedures are approved in writing by the Commission.
A facility operator’s security department operating procedures shall, at a minimum, include:
A security zone plan for the facility, employing fixed security posts and roving security officers designed to ensure:
The physical safety of employees of and invitees to the facility;
The safeguarding of assets;
Compliance with all applicable laws and regulations including Commission approved internal controls and operating procedures;
That the following individuals are identified, prohibited from entering the facility, and, if necessary, immediately removed from the facility:
An intoxicated individual;
An individual who is mandatorily excluded in accordance with State Government Article, §9-1A-24(d), Annotated Code of Maryland; and
An individual who is voluntarily excluded in accordance State Government Article, §9-1A-24(e), Annotated Code of Maryland; and

That an individual under the age of 21 years is identified, prohibited from accessing the gaming floor in accordance with State Government Article, §9-1A-24(c), Annotated Code of Maryland, and, if necessary, immediately removed from the gaming floor;
Procedures and controls addressing:
Facility access controls including:
An access badge system;
If utilized, specifications pertaining to a computerized access control system; and
Administrative responsibility over a manual or computerized access control system;
A temporary access credential;
Key controls;
Emergency alarm and fire command responsibilities including communication protocols with the surveillance department;
Evacuation of the facility in the event of fire or other emergency;

The identification and immediate removal of an intoxicated individual, an individual under the age of 21 years, an individual who is mandatorily excluded, and an individual who is voluntarily excluded;
Player disputes under Regulation .47 of this chapter; and
The notice requirements of §C(4) of this regulation;
A security department incident log:
Maintained by security department employees in:
A book with bound numbered pages that cannot be readily removed; or
An electronic format equipped with software that prevents modification of an entry after it has been initially entered into the system; and
Documenting the following:
Assignment number of the incident;
Date and time;
Name and Commission license of the department member covering the incident;
Nature of the incident; and
Resolution of the incident; and
A requirement that a facility operator notice the Commission on detection of:
An individual engaged in, attempting to engage in, or suspected of cheating, theft, embezzlement, or other illegal activities;
An individual possessing a firearm, electronic control device, dangerous weapon, or other device or object prohibited under Regulation .49 of this chapter; or
An individual who is:
Under the age of 21 years;
Intoxicated;
Mandatorily excluded in accordance with State Government Article, §9-1A-24(d), Annotated Code of Maryland; or
Voluntarily excluded in accordance State Government Article, §9-1A-24(e), Annotated Code of Maryland.

At least 60 days before video lottery terminal or table game operations are to commence, a facility operator shall submit its security department minimum staffing plan to the Commission for review and written approval.
A facility operator may not commence operations until its security department minimum staffing plan is approved in writing by the Commission.
A security department minimum staffing plan shall assess, on a per-shift basis, the minimum number of on-duty security department employees necessary to:
Ensure the physical safety of employees of and invitees to the facility;
Effectively safe guard assets;
Comply with all applicable laws and regulations including Commission-approved internal controls and operating procedures;
Monitor the facility to ensure that the following individuals are identified, prohibited from entering the facility, and, if necessary, immediately removed from the facility:
An intoxicated individual;
An individual who is mandatorily excluded in accordance with State Government Article, §9-1A-24(d), Annotated Code of Maryland; and
An individual who is voluntarily excluded in accordance State Government Article, §9-1A-24(e), Annotated Code of Maryland; and

Monitor the gaming floor to ensure that an individual under the age of 21 years is identified, prohibited from accessing the gaming floor in accordance with State Government Article, §9-1A-24(c), Annotated Code of Maryland and, if necessary, immediately removed from the gaming floor.
A facility operator’s proposed security department minimum staffing plan shall consider:
Square footage and layout of the facility;
Number and configuration of video lottery terminals and table games;
Use of fixed and roving security posts;
Activity level on a per-shift basis and identify it as slow, normal, or peak; and
Department supervisory needs.

A facility operator may not implement a change or amendment in the security department minimum staffing plan approved by the Commission under §B of this regulation without the prior written approval of the Commission.

At least 60 days before video lottery terminal operations are set to commence, a facility operator shall submit to the Commission for review and approval internal audit department operating standards and procedures that:
Meet the requirements of Regulation .10E(6)(b) of this chapter;
Conform to this regulation; and
Ensure that an internal audit is conducted in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards in the United States.
A facility operator's internal audit department operating procedures and standards shall, at a minimum, require the internal audit department to:
Work independently of the departments of the facility that are subject to audit;
Assess whether the facility's internal controls comply with applicable law and Commission directives;
Test the facility's compliance with its internal controls;
Immediately report a deficiency in, or noncompliance with, the facility's internal controls to:
The audit committee;
The chief executive officer;
Management; and
The Commission;
Recommend resolution for eliminating a deficiency in, or noncompliance with, the facilitys internal control system;
Meet periodically with the audit committee or director of internal audit;
Perform audits of:

Unless an alternate risk assessment and audit plan is submitted in writing and approved in writing by the Commission, all departments of the facility that are designated under §§C and D of this regulation; and
A department of the facility designated by the Commission;
Prepare an audit report for each audit conducted;
Accurately document the audit process and results in an audit report that, at a minimum, shall include:
Audit objectives;
Audit procedures and scope;
Findings and conclusions;
A recommendation for addressing a deficiency in, or noncompliance with, the facility's internal controls;
Resolution of all exceptions; and
Management's response;
Submit audit reports to the Commission on a schedule specified by the Commission; and
Verify that:
A deficiency or noncompliance revealed during an audit has been corrected; and
An exception disclosed during an audit has been resolved.
The audit department shall audit at least semiannually the functions and operations of the facility's:
Cashiers' cage;
Main bank;
Collection of cash storage boxes;
Cash count;
Revenue audit;
Operations department;
Key control; and
Table game operations.
The audit department shall audit at least annually:
Responsible gaming program;
Security department;
Currency transaction reporting;
Suspicious activity reporting;
Information technology controls;
Surveillance department; and
Player tracking system.
The internal audit department shall conduct an audit on an unannounced basis when possible.

section.heading: Access to Central Monitor and Control System Equipment.

para.text: Central monitor and control system equipment shall reside in an area physically segregated from other systems and equipment utilized by the facility operator which conforms to the requirements of COMAR 36.03.11.03.

At least 10 days before video lottery terminal operations are to commence, the Commission shall issue to the facility operator a list of individuals that it has approved to have access to the central monitor and control system equipment under State Government Article, §9-1A-02(c)(5), Annotated Code of Maryland.
A facility operator may not implement a change or amendment in its approved access list without the prior written approval of the Commission.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing physical access to central monitor and control system equipment located in the facility.
Central monitor and control system equipment may be accessed by:
An individual on the list described under §B of this regulation;
A compliance agent of the Commission; and
Commission staff authorized by the Director.
The facility operator’s internal controls shall require:
All keys which access the segregated area where the central monitor and control system equipment resides to be maintained by representatives of the:
Commission; and
Central monitor and control system operator; and

An individual requiring access to the segregated area where the central monitor and control system equipment resides who is not included on the Commission-approved access list maintained under §B of this regulation to be:
Authorized by the Commission; and
At all times, escorted by a Commission compliance agent, or Commission staff authorized by the Director; and
Reported in the entry log maintained in accordance with §G of this regulation.
The Commission shall maintain an entry log for the segregated area where the central monitor and control system equipment resides which is:
Kept inside the segregated area in a book with bound numbered pages that cannot be readily removed; and
Utilized by an individual entering the segregated area to record:
Date and time of entering;
Entering individual’s name and department or affiliation;
Reason for entering;
Name of the individual authorizing the individual’s entry into the segregated area; and
Date and time of exiting.

A facility operator shall have on, adjacent, or proximate to the gaming floor a physical structure known as a cashiers' cage to house the cashiers and to serve as the central location in the facility for:
The custody of the cash, accounting records, and forms and documents required under this chapter to conduct video lottery and table game operations;
The initial financial consolidation of all transactions pertaining to video lottery terminal and table game activity; and
Other functions normally associated with the operation of a cashiers' cage.
A cashiers’ cage shall include the following design features:
A manually triggered silent alarm system connected:
Directly to the security department; or
Directly, or through a documented communication protocol, to the monitor room of the surveillance department;
A double door entry and exit system that will not permit an individual to pass through the second door until the first door is securely locked, as follows:
The first door leading from the gaming floor shall be controlled by the security department, the surveillance department, or a Commission-approved computerized access control system.
The second door leading into the cashiers’ cage shall be controlled by the cashiers' cage or a Commission-approved computerized access control system.
The double door entry and exit system shall be equipped with surveillance capability sufficient to allow monitoring of:
All ingress and egress; and
The interior compartment; and
Both doors of the double door entry and exit system shall be equipped with:
Separate locks with a key or release mechanism which is different on each door; and
Locks which are operational in the event of a power failure; and
Any entrance to the cashiers’ cage that is not a double door entry and exit system shall be equipped as an alarmed emergency exit door.
A facility may have one or more satellite cages physically separate from the cashiers' cage which:
May perform all of the functions of a cashiers' cage authorized by this chapter; and
Shall be equipped with an alarm system in compliance with §B(1) of this regulation.
A facility operator shall make readily available to the Commission:
An access control matrix indicating which employee job descriptions are authorized to have access to the cashiers’ cage and any satellite cage; and
A list of employees, with license number, who are authorized:
To have access to the:
Cashiers’ cage and any satellite cage;
Keys to the manual locks securing the double door entry and exit system; and
Release button on magnetic locks securing the double door entry and exit system;
To activate or deactivate alarm systems for the cashiers' cage and any satellite cage; and
To grant access to the cashiers’ cage and any satellite cage through the access control matrix or a computerized access control system.

section.heading: Accounting Controls for a Cashiers’ Cage.

para.text: A facility operator may only conduct transactions with individuals at its cashiers’ cage and any satellite cage during the hours of operation approved by the Commission for the facility under COMAR 36.03.11.02.
A facility operator shall at all times maintain in its cashiers’ cage a reserve cash bankroll sufficient to pay all winning wagers.
A facility operator shall:
Compute its reserve cash bankroll requirement based on a calendar year; and
Submit its computation to the Commission:
At least 30 days prior to the commencement of video lottery or table game operations; and
On or before January 30 of each year subsequent to the year in which operations are commenced.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing the segregation of the cashiers’ cage and the general conduct of cashiers’ cage transactions.
A facility operator’s internal controls shall require:
The cashiers' cage and any satellite cage to be physically segregated by personnel and function as follows:
General cashiers shall be responsible for:
An individual imprest inventory of cash;
Receipt and payout of cash, negotiable instruments, gaming tickets, and other documentation from and to players subject to the limitations imposed under this chapter;
Preparation of jackpot documents; and
Other functions designated by the facility operator which are not incompatible with the functions of a general cashier; and
Main bank cashiers shall be responsible for:
Receipt of cash, negotiable instruments, gaming tickets, jackpot, and other documentation from general cashiers in exchange for cash or documentation;
Replenishment of ticket redemption units and automated jackpot payout machines;
Receipt of unsecured cash and unsecured gaming tickets;
Receipt of cash and documentation from the count room;
Preparation of the overall cashiers’ cage reconciliation;
Preparation of bank deposits;
Compliance with reserve cash bankroll requirements;
Receipt of original and redemption copies of counter checks;
Receipt from general cashiers of documentation supporting counter check substitution, consolidation, or redemption; and
Other functions designated by the facility operator which are not incompatible with the functions of a main bank cashier;
Each general cashier and main bank cashier to prepare a cashiers’ count sheet on each shift:
Recording the amount of the inventory in the window or bank;
Reconciling the total closing inventory with the total opening inventory; and
Including the signature of the:
Outgoing general or main bank cashier; and
Incoming general or main bank cashier;
At the end of the gaming day, the cashiers’ cage to forward a copy of each cashiers’ count sheet and related documentation to the accounting department for:
Agreement of opening and closing inventories; and
Comparison of forms or documents; and

No more than 48 hours after the discovery of an employee’s unresolved cage or count room overage or shortage of $500 or more, a facility operator shall submit a written report to the Commission describing:
The reason for the overage or shortage and corrective action taken or adjustment made; or
That a notice of investigation is ongoing and the written report will be submitted within the following 48 hours.
A facility operator may accept a negotiable instrument in the form of a check meeting the requirements of this regulation from a player to enable the player to take part in gaming.
A facility operator may accept a check only during the hours of operation approved by the Commission for the facility under COMAR 36.03.11.02.
A facility operator may accept a personal check that is:
Made payable to the facility operator;
Drawn on a bank, savings and loan association, or credit union subject to federal or State banking regulation;
Drawn for a specific amount;
Currently dated, not postdated; and
Payable on demand.
Subject to the requirements of §§E and J of this regulation, a facility operator may accept a check issued by a:
Facility operator; and
Person that:
Is an affiliate of the facility operator; and
Holds a valid gaming license in another jurisdiction.
A facility operator shall only accept a check under §D of this regulation which has been issued to an individual as:
Employment compensation; or
A payout in connection with gaming activity.
A facility operator may not:
Except as provided under §C of this regulation, accept a check that is payable to an individual, including:
A Social Security check;
An unemployment insurance check;
A disability payment check; or
A public assistance check; or
Except for a check issued under §§E, J, and K of this regulation, accept from a player under this regulation a check or multiple checks which in the aggregate exceed $50,000 during a gaming day.
For a personal check equaling or exceeding $5,000, a facility operator shall confirm the availability of funds by:
Directly contacting the bank, savings and loan association, or credit union upon which the check is drawn;
Obtaining an authorization and guarantee of the check from a check verification and warranty service licensed as a contractor under COMAR 36.03.02.14; or
Alternate procedures addressing acceptance and verification of personal checks submitted in writing and approved by the Commission.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter, procedures addressing the acceptance and verification of checks meeting the requirements of this regulation.
A facility operator's internal controls shall require a check accepted from a player by a general cashier to be:
If a personal check other than an electronic check, restrictively endorsed for deposit only to the bank account designated for this purpose by the facility operator and:
Initialed by the accepting general cashier;
Date and time stamped;
Documented on the face of the check the number on the player's government-issued photographic identification; and
If a personal check equaling or exceeding $5,000, confirmed for availability of funds under §G of this regulation;
Verified for signature authenticity by a general cashier who shall:
Obtain from the player one form of identification that is a valid, unexpired government-issued photographic identification; and
Satisfactorily compare the:
Signature of the player on the personal check or endorsing the payroll or payout check with the signature on an identification credential; and
Player's physical appearance with the photograph contained on the valid, unexpired government-issued photographic identification presented by the player;
If presented by a player as a payroll or payout check under §E of this regulation, confirmed to have been issued as employment compensation or as a payout in connection with gaming activity; and
Immediately exchanged for:
Cash;
If the facility operator has the capability, a gaming ticket;
A chip or plaque; or
A customer deposit account in accordance with this chapter.
A facility operator that is a designated Agency customer resource center may accept an Agency check for Lottery prize winnings for up to $25,000 under COMAR 36.02.06.01.
On a single gaming day, a facility operator may accept a check or multiple checks which:
In the aggregate do not exceed $250,000; and
Were issued to an individual as a payout in connection with gaming activity by:
A facility operator; or
A person that:
Is an affiliate of a facility operator; and
Holds a valid gaming license in another jurisdiction.

A facility operator may accept a negotiable instrument in the form of a wire transfer or ACH transfer from a player to enable the player to take part in gaming or to pay an outstanding debt to a facility operator.

A facility operator shall record in its cashiers’ cage accountability any funds accepted by wire transfer or ACH transfer with no documented business purpose other than to enable a player to take part in gaming within 24 hours of receipt of the wire transfer.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing the acceptance, verification, and sending of wire transfers or ACH transfers meeting the requirements of this regulation.
A facility operator’s internal controls shall:

Require preparation of a cashiers’ cage wire transfer or ACH transfer log to record the following information pertaining to a wire transfer or ACH transfer accepted by a facility operator on behalf of a player:
A sequential number assigned by the facility operator to the wire transfer or ACH transfer accepted;
Date and time notice of the wire transfer or ACH transfer was received;
Name of the financial institution to which the funds were sent;
Amount transferred;
Name of the player for whose benefit the funds were accepted;
The name of the financial institution from which the funds were transferred;
The method by which the facility operator was notified of the receipt of the wire transfer or ACH transfer;
If noticed by telephone, the name and title of the individual providing notice;
The signature of the cashiers' cage employee receiving and recording the information required by this section; and
If applicable, a notation that the wire transfer or ACH transfer has been returned under §E of this regulation;
Require that a cashiers’ cage supervisor other than the cashiers’ cage employee who initially documented acceptance of the wire transfer or ACH transfer:
Independently confirm:
Date, time, and method by which the facility operator was notified of the wire transfer or ACH transfer; and
If noticed by telephone, the name and title of the individual providing notice;
Record the date and time of confirmation in the wire transfer or ACH transfer log; and
Sign the wire transfer or ACH transfer log as completing the confirmation process;
Document the procedures used to:
Establish, verify, and document the identity of a player sending a wire transfer or ACH transfer;
Make the wire transfer or ACH transfer proceeds available to a player at the cashiers’ cage; and
Adjust the cashiers' cage accountability;

Require preparation of a cashiers’ cage wire transfer or ACH transfer log to record the following information pertaining to a wire transfer or ACH transfer sent by a facility operator on behalf of a player:
A sequential number assigned by the facility operator to the wire transfer or ACH transfer sent;
Name of the player;
Date of the transaction;
Amount wired;
Source of funds;
The name and address of the financial institution to which the funds were wired;
Account number to which the funds are credited;
If the request to send a wire transfer or ACH transfer is made in person at the cashiers’ cage, the signature of the player;

If the request to send a wire transfer or ACH transfer is not made in person at the cashiers’ cage, documentation supporting the receipt of a request by the facility operator to send a wire transfer or ACH transfer on behalf of a player;
The signature of the cashiers' cage employee receiving and recording the information required by this regulation; and
The signature of the cashiers’ cage supervisor or accounting department supervisor authorizing the wire transfer or ACH transfer; and
Document the procedures used to:
Establish, verify, and document the identity of a player requesting that a wire transfer or ACH transfer be sent;
Send the wire transfer or ACH transfer; and
Adjust the cashiers' cage accountability.
A facility operator shall take immediate action to return to a player by wire transfer or ACH transfer funds initially accepted by wire transfer or ACH transfer under the following circumstances:
The wired funds received by the facility operator have no documented business purpose other than to enable a player to take part in gaming;
All or a substantial portion of the wired funds remain in the facility operator's cashiers' cage accountability more than 14 days following transfer to that accountability; and
The player has engaged in minimal or no video lottery or table game play since receipt of the wire transfer or ACH transfer.
A wire transfer or ACH transfer returned in accordance with §E of this regulation shall be sent to the same individual, financial institution, and account number from which the funds were debited.
Return of a wire transfer or ACH transfer shall be recorded in the wire transfer or ACH transfer log maintained under §D of this regulation.
A facility operator may accept a negotiable instrument in the form of a cash equivalent from a player to enable the player to take part in gaming.
A facility operator may accept a cash equivalent only during the hours of operation approved by the Commission for the facility under COMAR 36.03.11.02.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing the acceptance and verification of cash equivalents meeting the requirements of this chapter.
A facility operator’s internal controls shall:
Enumerate the type of cash equivalents complying with this chapter to be accepted;
Detail the specific verification procedures required by each issuer;
Require that a general cashier:
Perform the specific verification procedures required by each issuer;
Prepare and maintain documentation evidencing the verification of a cash equivalent accepted; and
Examine a cash equivalent for counterfeiting, forgery, or alteration;
Detail the criteria for cashiers' cage supervisor involvement in the verification process; and
Include procedures for verifying the authenticity of a player’s signature on a cash equivalent in conformance with the signature authentication procedures in Regulation .20 of this chapter.
A facility operator may establish a customer deposit account for a player to enable the player to take part in gaming.

A facility operator shall perform all procedures required by this chapter before depositing funds accepted by means of check, wire transfer, cash equivalent, or other negotiable instrument into a customer deposit account.
A facility operator may accept a customer deposit only during the hours of operation approved by the Commission for the facility under COMAR 36.03.11.02.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing the acceptance of customer deposits meeting the requirements of this regulation.
A facility operator’s internal controls shall:
Require acceptance of customer deposits at:
The cashiers’ cage; or
An off-site customer service location;
Require preparation of a receipt documenting:
Amount deposited;
Date of the deposit; and
The signature of the general cashier accepting the customer deposit;
Provide for full or partial withdrawal of a customer deposit:
By a player at the cashiers’ cage; or
Upon receipt by the facility operator of a written request for withdrawal for which validity has been established; and
