Include procedures for documenting acceptance and withdrawal of customer deposits including a verification of the authenticity of a player’s signature on a customer deposit withdrawal document in conformance with the signature authentication procedures in Regulation .20 of this chapter.

For the purposes of this regulation, “derogatory information” means any information associated with a credit account indicating that the account is partially or completely uncollectible, has had checks returned unpaid, or has required settlement, lien, judgment, or other collection efforts by a gaming operator.
A facility operator may not extend a line of credit to a player to enable the player to take part in gaming which exceeds the player’s authorized credit limit.
A facility operator may extend credit to a player if a:
Player submits a credit application in writing in accordance with this regulation;
Facility operator complies with the:
Credit application verification requirements of Regulation .25 of this chapter; and
Credit authorization and credit file documentation requirements of this regulation;
Credit is issued:
By acceptance of a negotiable instrument in the form of a counter check under Regulation .26 or .27 of this chapter; and
During the hours of operation approved by the Commission for the facility under COMAR 36.03.11.02; and
Player’s outstanding counter check balance does not at any time exceed the player’s authorized credit limit.
A facility operator shall accept a credit application submitted by a player:
During the hours of operation approved by the Commission for the facility under COMAR 36.03.11.02;
By mail; and
By electronic submission.
A facility operator shall create and maintain a credit file for a player applying for an extension of credit or authorized counter check privileges.
A credit file shall:

Be prepared, either manually or by computer, by a general cashier or credit department representative with no incompatible functions including the ability to authorize credit or approve a change in a credit limit;
Contain the credit application submitted by the player documenting, at a minimum, the following:
Name;
Residential address;
Personal telephone number;
Personal checking account information including:
Name and routing number of a bank, savings and loan or credit union subject to federal or State banking regulation on which a counter check is to be drawn;
Account number; and
A representation that the player is individually authorized to draw on the account;
Credit limit requested by the player;
Good faith estimate of:
Outstanding indebtedness including gaming related credit limits and outstanding balances; and
The amount and source of income and assets that support the requested credit limit; and
Signature of the player:
Acknowledging the request for an extension of credit and counter check privileges;
Certifying that all information provided on the application is true and accurate;
Authorizing the facility operator to conduct the due diligence it deems appropriate prior to the credit decision; and
Acknowledging that the player may be subject to civil or criminal liability if any material information provided is willfully false; and
Document, in accordance with §J of this regulation, the credit limit initially authorized by the facility operator for a player and any change in that credit limit.
A facility operator may:
Consider a checking account of a sole proprietorship owned by a player to be a personal checking account; and
Not consider a partnership or corporate checking account to be a personal checking account even if a player is individually authorized to draw on the account.
Prior to authorizing an extension of credit, the facility operator shall verify the information on the credit application submitted by the player in accordance with Regulation .25 of this chapter.
A facility operator shall restrict authority to extend credit or to approve a change in a credit limit to the following employees:

If the facility operator’s table of organization includes a separate credit department, cage credit director, credit manager, cage/credit shift manager, or credit executive who has no involvement with the verifications required under Regulation .25 of this chapter;
A principal employee or a credit manager who has no involvement in the verifications required under Regulation .25 of this chapter; and
A credit committee composed of principal employees:
Which may authorize credit as a group; and
Whose members may not act individually to authorize credit unless an individual meets the requirements of §I(1) or (2) of this regulation.
A facility operator shall record in a player’s credit file the initial decision to authorize an extension of credit including:
The credit limit assigned to the player;
Date and time the credit limit was activated;
Information used to support the extension of credit including the source of the information, if such information is not otherwise recorded in the credit file under Regulation .25 of this chapter;
If applicable, a brief explanation as to why:
The credit limit authorized deviates from the credit limit requested by the player in the credit application; and
Credit was authorized when the verification process conducted under Regulation .25 of this chapter disclosed derogatory information; and
The signature or authorization code of the employee authorizing the extension of credit.
A facility operator shall require a request for a change in credit limit to be in writing and include:
Date and time of the request;
New limit requested by the player; and
Signature of the player.
Prior to approving a change in a player’s authorized credit limit, a facility operator shall:

Verify the player’s current gaming related credit limits and outstanding balances in accordance with Regulation .25 of this chapter unless the facility operator verified that same information earlier in the same gaming day;

If a player’s increased credit limit will exceed $2,500, verify the player's outstanding indebtedness in accordance with Regulation .25 of this chapter unless the facility operator verified the player’s outstanding indebtedness in the previous 12 months;

Verify the player’s personal checking account information in accordance with Regulation .25 of this chapter unless the facility operator verified the player’s checking account information in the previous 24 months;
Review player rating system data regarding the amount and frequency of play subsequent to the initial extension of credit; and
Document in the player’s credit file:
If approved, the change in credit limit;
If disapproved, the reason the credit limit was not changed;
The verifications required by this regulation;
The player’s rating in the player rating system on the date the change in credit limit was authorized; and
The signature or authorization code of the employee responsible for the assessment of the request for a change in credit limit.
A facility operator may approve a “this trip only” increase in a credit limit without performing the verifications required by §L of this regulation if:
The increase:
Is in effect for a single trip to the facility consisting of consecutive gaming days; and
Does not exceed 25 percent of the currently authorized credit limit; and
The increase is documented in the player’s credit file including the signature or authorization code of the employee approving the “this trip only” credit limit increase.
A facility operator may approve a “this trip only” increase in a credit limit after performing the verifications required by §L of this regulation if:
The increase:
Is in effect for a single trip to the facility consisting of consecutive gaming days; and
Exceeds 25 percent of the currently authorized credit limit; and
The increase is documented in the player’s credit file including the signature or authorization code of the employee approving the “this trip only” credit limit increase.

A facility operator may not accept a counter check from a player before the decision to authorize an extension of credit, approve a change in a credit limit, or approve a “this trip only” credit limit increase is recorded in the credit file, including the signature or authorization code of the employee authorizing the extension of credit or credit limit increase.
A facility operator shall suspend the counter check privileges of a player:
On receipt of:
Derogatory information;
Information that indicates that a player’s financial position has materially deteriorated; or
A returned check; or
Who has been inactive at the facility’s video lottery terminals and table games for more than 24 months.
A facility operator may reinstate the counter check privileges of a player suspended under §P of this regulation after:
Completion of the verification requirements of Regulation .25 of this chapter;
Receipt as a result of those verifications of information supporting the authorized credit limit; and
If applicable, payment in full of a returned check.

If derogatory information develops pertaining to a player’s account at a facility, a facility operator shall report the derogatory information to the same casino credit bureau it utilizes to verify gaming related credit limits and outstanding balances under Regulation .25 of this chapter within 24 hours of development of the derogatory information.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing the issuance of credit including:
Identifying the employee positions authorized to extend credit or approve a change in a credit limit; and
Creation and maintenance of the credit file.

Prior to authorizing an extension of credit and counter check privileges under Regulation .24 of this chapter, a facility operator shall verify the information on the credit application submitted by the player in accordance with this regulation.
The verification of credit application information required under this regulation:
Shall be conducted by a general cashier or credit department representative with no incompatible functions including the ability to authorize credit or approve a change in a credit limit;
Shall be documented in the player’s credit file by recording the following:
Source of the verification;
Date and time;
Method of verification; and
Signature of the verifying general cashier or credit department representative; and
May be performed telephonically if the facility operator:
Requests documentation confirming the information verified telephonically;
Documents the request for confirming information in the player’s credit file; and
Maintains all confirming documentation received in the player’s credit file.
If a player’s credit limit will exceed $2,500, the facility operator shall verify the player’s residential address with:
A consumer credit bureau;
The player’s bank; or
An alternative source which may not include examination of additional identification credentials or other documentation presented by the player at the facility.
The facility operator shall:
Verify the player’s current gaming related credit limits and outstanding balances with:
A casino credit bureau; or
Each gaming operator with whom the player has an outstanding limit;
Document the player’s current gaming related credit limits and outstanding balances in the credit file by recording for each gaming related credit limit:
The date the player’s credit account was established;
Amount of the current authorized credit limit;
Current balance; and
Any derogatory information noted in the player’s account; and
If applicable, document in the credit file that no gaming related credit limit or outstanding balance information is available on the player.
A facility operator shall:
Verify the player’s outstanding indebtedness with a:
Consumer credit bureau; or
Casino credit bureau; and
Document the player’s outstanding indebtedness in the credit file by recording:
If available, the current balance of each debt obligation; and
Any derogatory information noted.
A facility operator shall:
Verify the player’s personal checking account information with:
The player’s bank; or
A bank verification service; and
Document the player’s personal checking account information by recording in the credit file:
Confirmation that the account is a personal account on which the player may draw individually;
Account number;
Date the account was opened;
If available, average balance of the account for the last 12 months;
Balance in the account; and
Name and title of the person supplying the information.
A facility operator shall verify that the player is not an individual who is:
Under 21 years of age;
Voluntarily suspended from counter check privileges under Regulation .32 of this chapter;
Mandatorily excluded in accordance with State Government Article, §9-1A-24(d), Annotated Code of Maryland; or
Voluntarily excluded in accordance State Government Article, §9-1A-24(e), Annotated Code of Maryland.
A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures:
Identifying those employees authorized to conduct the verifications required under this regulation; and
Addressing the verification process required under this regulation.

section.heading: Counter Check Issuance at the Cashiers’ Cage.

para.text: Subject to the requirements of this chapter, a facility operator may accept a negotiable instrument in the form of a counter check from a player at the cashiers’ cage to enable the player to take part in gaming.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing the issuance of a counter check at the cashiers’ cage.
A facility operator’s internal controls shall include:
The use of a three-part computer-generated counter check that:
Consists of an original, issuance, and accounting copy;
Is initiated on receipt by a general cashier of a request for counter check document; and
Is serially numbered and issued;
Procedures and controls addressing the identification of a player which include:
A requirement that a one-part request for counter check document be prepared which includes:
Amount requested;
If a facility operator has the capability of offering a gaming ticket as an alternative to cash, an indication as to the desired form of payment; and
Signature of the player;
A requirement that a general cashier obtain from the player a valid form of unexpired government-issued photographic identification;
A requirement that a general cashier satisfactorily compare the:
Signature of the player on the counter check request document with the signature on the identification credential; and
Player’s physical appearance with the photograph contained on the valid, unexpired government-issued photographic identification presented by the player;
A requirement that a general cashier record on the counter check request document the:
Number on the player’s government-issued photographic identification; and
Signature of the general cashier;

An option for a general cashier who has on that same shift previously verified the identity of a player by credential review in accordance with §C(2)(b) of this regulation to satisfy the requirements of this regulation by recording on the counter check request document:
The series number of the counter check for which the identity of the player was established by credential review; and
Signature of the general cashier;

An option for a facility operator who has created a signature file on a player prior to the completion by the player of a request for counter check document to satisfy the requirements of this regulation by having the general cashier:
Confirm that the player’s signature on the counter check request document matches the signature in the signature file; and
Sign the counter check request document; and
A requirement that a credential review in accordance with §C(2)(b) and (c) of this regulation is a prerequisite to creation of a player signature file;

A requirement that prior to issuing a counter check a general cashier confirm with a check bank cashier or through the video lottery system that the amount requested does not exceed the player’s credit limit;
A requirement that all copies of a computer-generated counter check include the following information:
Name of the player;
Name of the bank, savings and loan, or credit union on which the counter check is to be drawn;
Date and time;
Amount of the counter check;
Location of preparation of the counter check;
Signature of a cashiers’ cage supervisor; and
Signature or identification code of the preparer of the counter check;
A requirement that the back of the original copy of the counter check contain a restrictive endorsement "for deposit only" to the facility operator’s designated bank account;
Procedures and controls over the counter check issuance process which require:
A cashiers’ cage supervisor to sign all copies of the counter check after confirming that the counter check was prepared for the amount the player recorded on the counter check request document;
A player to sign all copies of the counter check in the presence of the same general cashier who verified the player’s identification and prepared the counter check;
A general cashier to immediately exchange the counter check for:
Cash;
If a facility operator has the capability, a gaming ticket; or
A customer deposit account in accordance with this chapter; and
A general cashier to distribute the copies of the counter check as follows:

The original copy of the counter check shall be expeditiously transferred to the check bank directly or to a security department employee for transportation to the cashiers’ cage if the counter check is issued in a satellite cage;

The issuance copy of the counter check shall be maintained by the general cashier to serve as documentation supporting the exchange of cash, a gaming ticket, or a customer deposit for the counter check; and
The accounting copy of the counter check shall be attached by the general cashier to the counter check request document and forwarded to the accounting department;
If utilized, procedures and controls addressing:
Use of a signature exemplar;
Creation of a player signature file; and
Generation of a gaming ticket at the cashiers’ cage;
Procedures and controls addressing:
Voided counter checks;
The use and location of accounting drop boxes; and
Audit procedures performed by the facility operator’s accounting department at the conclusion of each gaming day;

Details which establish the ability of the facility operator’s video lottery system to ensure that a three-part computer-generated counter check is not susceptible to change or deletion from the system after preparation; and
Procedures utilized to issue a manual counter check which:
Are to be utilized only when the video lottery system is unable to generate a counter check;
Conform to the requirements of this regulation;
Require use of a serially pre-numbered three-part counter check consisting of an original, issuance, and accounting copy, residing in a book, wiz machine, or functional equivalent;
Require manual counter checks to be maintained in a secured locked cabinet in the cashiers’ cage; and
Require the key to the cabinet in §C(10)(d) of this regulation to be:
Controlled by the security department or the cage department employees responsible for the control of and accounting for the unused supply of counter checks; and
Limited to sign out by a cashiers’ cage shift manager or cashiers’ cage manager.
Electronic Credit System.
A facility operator may use an electronic credit system approved by the Commission to process electronic counter check transactions.
The facility operator may access the player’s file in the electronic credit system using a portable device or other method approved by the Commission.
The electronic credit system shall be capable of maintaining independently, or in conjunction with another computer system, as approved by the Commission:
A digital photograph and signature of the player;
Encrypted employee and player personal identification numbers;
For each player account and transaction, the information required to be recorded by §C of this regulation;
A record of each electronic transaction, printable in the check bank, which shall include at least:
Date and time;
Transaction type;
Document number;
Location;
Player name and account number; and
Amount;
A record of each electronic transaction for which the player has successfully entered the player’s personal identification number and digital signature in the system;
A record of voided transactions and the reason for the void; and
Any other information the Commission requests.

section.heading: Counter Check Issuance at a Video Lottery Terminal or Table Game.

para.text: Subject to the limitations of this chapter, a facility operator may accept a negotiable instrument in the form of a counter check from a player at a video lottery terminal or table game to enable the player to take part in gaming.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter, procedures addressing the issuance of a counter check at a video lottery terminal or table game.
A facility operator’s internal controls for a counter check exchanged for value chips or plaques at a gaming table shall include:
Use of a player signature file which shall:
Be established prior to the completion by a player of a request for counter check document at the table game; and
Require an identification credential review in accordance with Regulation .26C(2) of this chapter;
Procedures and controls addressing the identification of the player which include:
A requirement that a floorperson satisfactorily compare the:
Signature of the player on a form with the signature on the identification credential; and
Player’s physical appearance with the photograph contained on the valid form of unexpired government-issued photographic identification presented by the player;
A requirement that a floorperson record on the form the:
Number on the player’s government-issued photographic identification; and
Signature of the floorperson;
A requirement that a floorperson or above shall:
Obtain the player’s signature, on a form, which shall be compared to the signature contained within a player signature file;
Sign the form indicating that the signature of the player on the form matches the signature in the player signature file; and
Attach the form to the accounting copy of the counter check exchanged by the player prior to forwarding it to the accounting department;
A requirement that after the player’s identity has been verified by the floorperson or above, staff shall:

Ensure that subsequent verification of the player’s identity during the same shift and in the same gaming pit is satisfied by the employee who performed the initial verification signing a form attesting to the player’s identity before each subsequent counter check is exchanged;
Ensure that the form includes the player’s name and the serial number of the initial counter check exchanged by the player; and
Ensure that the form attaches to the accounting copy of the subsequent counter check prior to forwarding the accounting copy to the accounting department; and
A requirement that a floorperson or above attest to the identity of the player which includes:
The floorperson or above record the floorperson’s or above’s gaming license number and sign a form or the counter check attesting to the player’s identity; and
If used, the form is attached to the accounting copy of the counter check exchanged by the player prior to forwarding it to the accounting department;
A requirement that prior to issuing a counter check, the floorperson or above determines the player’s remaining credit limit from the cage or casino management system;
A requirement that all copies of a computer-generated counter check include the following information:
Name of the player;
Name of the bank, savings and loan, or credit union on which the counter check is to be drawn;
Date and time;
Amount of the counter check;
Location of preparation of the counter check;
Signature of a gaming operations department supervisor; and
Signature or identification code of the preparer of the counter check;
A requirement that the floorperson or above present the original and all duplicate copies of the counter check to the player for signature;

A requirement that the back of the original copy of the counter check contain a restrictive endorsement “for deposit only” to the facility operator’s designated bank account after being transferred to the check bank; and
Procedures and controls over the counter check issuance process which require:
A floorperson to receive the signed counter check directly from the player;
The issuance copy of the counter check to be immediately given to the dealer or boxperson to be exchanged for value chips or gaming plaques;
The issuance copy of the counter check to be deposited by the dealer or boxperson in the drop box;

The original copy of the counter check to be expeditiously transported to the cage where the original copy shall be maintained and controlled by the cage cashier designated to act as the check bank; and
The accounting copy of the counter check to be maintained and controlled by the pit clerk or above until forwarded to the accounting department.
A facility operator’s internal controls for a counter check exchanged for cash or gaming ticket directly at a video lottery terminal shall include:
Use of a player signature file which shall:
Be established prior to the completion by a player of a request for counter check document at the video lottery terminal; and
Require an identification credential review in accordance with Regulation .26C(2) of this chapter;
Procedures and controls addressing the identification of the player which include:

A gaming operations supervisor to obtain the amount of the requested counter check and the player’s signature on a one-part counter check request form and transport the counter check request form directly to the cage cashier; and
A cage cashier to compare the signature on the one-part counter check request form to the signature contained within a player signature file;
Procedures and controls over the counter check issuance process which require:
A general cashier to:
Prepare the counter check in accordance with this regulation;

Summon to the cashiers’ cage a verifying employee from the security department or gaming operations department provided the verifying employee is not the gaming operations department supervisor who transported the counter check request document to the cashiers’ cage;
Present the counter check request document, all copies of the counter check and the cash, gaming ticket, chip, or plaque to the gaming operations department supervisor and the verifying employee;

Obtain the signature of the gaming operations department supervisor on all copies of the counter check confirming that the amount of the counter check agrees with the amount on the counter check request document;

Obtain the signature of the verifying employee on the counter check request document confirming that the amount of cash, gaming ticket, chip, or plaque to be transported to the player agrees with the amount on the counter check and on the counter check request document; and

Release to the verifying employee the counter check request document, all copies of the counter check, and the cash, gaming ticket, chip, or plaque for transportation, in the presence of the gaming operations department supervisor who transported the counter check request to the cashiers’ cage, to the player;
A verifying employee to present all copies of the counter check to the player for signature in the presence of the gaming operations department supervisor;
A gaming operations department supervisor to compare the player’s signature on the counter check to the signature on the counter check request document;
A verifying employee to immediately exchange the counter check for:
Cash; or
If a facility operator has the capability, a gaming ticket;
A gaming operations department supervisor to:
Sign the back of the accounting copy confirming the exchange with the player; and
Drop the accounting copy of the counter check into an accounting drop box for forwarding to accounting;
A verifying employee to immediately return the original and issuance copies of the counter check to a general cashier; and
A general cashier to:

Expeditiously transfer the original copy of the counter check to the check bank directly or to a security department employee for transportation to the cashiers’ cage if the counter check is issued in a satellite cage; and
Attach the counter check request document to the accounting copy of the counter check to serve as documentation supporting the exchange of cash, gaming ticket, for the counter check.
Electronic Credit System.
A facility operator may use an electronic credit system approved by the Commission to process electronic counter check transactions.
The facility operator may access the player’s file in the electronic credit system using a portable device or other approved method.
The electronic credit system shall be capable of maintaining independently, or in conjunction with another computer system, as approved by the Commission:
A digital photograph and signature of the player;
Encrypted employee and player personal identification numbers;
For each player account and transaction, the information required to be recorded by §§C and D of this regulation;
A record of each electronic transaction, printable in the check bank, which shall include at least:
Date and time;
Transaction type;
Document number;
Location;
Player name and account number; and
Amount;
A record of each electronic transaction for which the player has successfully entered the player’s personal identification number and digital signature in the system;
A record of voided transactions and the reason for the void; and
Any other information the Commission requests.

section.heading: Counter Check Substitution, Consolidation, and Redemption.

para.text: A player to whom a counter check has been issued by a facility operator may use a personal check meeting the requirements of §B of this regulation to:
Substitute for a counter check which has not been deposited by the facility operator;
Consolidate two or more counter checks which have not been deposited by the facility operator; and
Redeem, partially or in full, a counter check which has not been deposited by a facility operator.
A personal check accepted by a facility operator in a substitution, consolidation, or redemption transaction shall:
Be drawn on an account which has been verified in accordance with Regulation .25 of this chapter;
Except as provided in §C of this regulation, comply with the requirements of Regulation .20 of this chapter; and
Be redeemed or deposited in accordance with Regulation .29 of this chapter.

If a personal check is accepted in an amount less than or equal to the amount of a counter check being partially or fully redeemed, the $30,000 limitation on acceptance of personal checks in Regulation .20F(2) of this chapter does not apply.

A player who has issued a replacement check to a facility operator may present another replacement check in a substitution, consolidation, or partial redemption transaction involving the original replacement check.
A replacement check accepted by a facility operator in a substitution, consolidation, or partial redemption transaction shall be:
Dated with the date of the initial counter check being substituted, consolidated, or partially redeemed; or

If the check is subject to Commission-approved internal controls which ensure that the date of the initial counter check being substituted, consolidated, or partially redeemed is used to determine the date on which the replacement check is deposited under Regulation .29 of this chapter, currently dated.

A facility operator may not accept a replacement check in substitution, consolidation, or partial redemption for the purpose of avoiding or delaying the deposit requirements for a counter check or replacement check under Regulation .29 of this chapter.
If a player has more than one counter check or replacement check which has not been deposited, the most recently dated check shall be redeemed first, except that:
If more than one check bears the same date, the player may choose the order in which to redeem the checks;

If, pursuant to Commission-approved internal controls, a facility operator does not require a replacement check used in a substitution, consolidation, or partial redemption transaction to be dated with the date of the initial counter check being substituted, consolidated, or partially redeemed, then the date of the initial counter check and not the date of the replacement check shall be used to determine the order in which outstanding checks are redeemed; and

If a facility operator receives a check through the mail or by other means approved by the Commission and the player requests that it be applied to a transaction having an earlier redemption date, the facility operator may apply the check according to the player’s request.
A facility operator may conduct a substitution, consolidation, and full or partial redemption transaction:
At the cashiers’ cage during the hours of operation approved by the Commission for the facility under COMAR 36.03.11.02;
By mail;
At an off-site customer service location; or
In a table game pit.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures and controls addressing the substitution, consolidation, and full or partial redemption of a counter check.
A facility operator may allow a player to redeem a counter check at a gaming table in exchange for gaming chips.
A facility operator’s internal controls for redeeming a counter check at a gaming table shall include:
A requirement that a redemption occur:
On the same gaming day the counter check is issued; and
In the same gaming pit where the counter check was issued and held for pit redemption;
A requirement that a general cashier or casino clerk:
Remove the original and all duplicate copies of the counter check from its secured location in the pit;
Prepare a two-part serially prenumbered pit redemption form in accordance with this regulation; and
Present the pit redemption form and the original and all duplicate copies of the counter check to the dealer or boxperson, in the presence of a floorperson or above;
Procedures and controls over the counter check redemption process which require:
A dealer or boxperson to verify that the amount of chips received from the player agrees with the amount of the original counter check and the pit redemption form;
The dealer or boxperson to place the gaming chips from the player into the table inventory;
The dealer or boxperson, and the floorperson to sign the pit redemption form;
The dealer or boxperson to deposit the original of the pit redemption form in the drop box;
The floorperson to return the original counter check to the player;
The floorperson to return the duplicate copies of the counter check and the duplicate copy of the pit redemption form to the general cashier or casino clerk;
The general cashier or casino clerk to forward the duplicate copies of the counter check to the check bank for processing; and
The cashiers’ cage to forward the duplicate copy of the pit redemption form to the casino accounting department at the end of the gaming day; and

A requirement that the general cashier or casino clerk record the following information on a two-part serially prenumbered pit redemption form residing in a book, wiz machine, or functional equivalent:
The date and time of redemption;
The identification number of the table game;
The player's name;
The counter check number and amount;
The signature of the general cashier or casino clerk;
The signature of the table game dealer or boxperson; and
The signature of the floorperson or above.
Electronic Credit System.
A facility operator may use an electronic credit system approved by the Commission to process electronic counter check transactions.
The facility operator may access the player’s file in the electronic credit system using a portable device or other method approved by the Commission.
The electronic credit system shall be capable of maintaining independently, or in conjunction with another computer system, as approved by the Commission:
A digital photograph and signature of the player;
Encrypted employee and player personal identification numbers;
For each player account and transaction, the information required to be recorded by §§B and E of this regulation;
A record of each electronic transaction, printable in the check bank, which shall include at least:
Date and time;
Transaction type;
Document number;
Location;
Player name and account number; and
Amount;
A record of each electronic transaction for which the player has successfully entered the player’s personal identification number and digital signature in the system;
A record of voided transactions and the reason for the void; and
Any other information the Commission requests.
A facility operator shall deposit a counter check in its bank account or present the counter check directly to the player’s bank:
No later than:
14 days after the date of the check for a check of $1,000 or less;
21 days after the date of the check for a check greater than $1,000 but not more than $2,500;
45 days after the date of the check for a check greater than $2,500; or
60 days after the date of the check for a check greater than $10,000; or
In accordance with a deposit schedule agreed to between the facility operator and the player if the deposit schedule:
Does not authorize deposit more than 60 days after the date of the check;
May not be amended or modified to change the deposit date of a counter check after acceptance of the counter check from the player; and
Was at the time of the initial authorization of credit or an approved change in a credit limit:
Agreed to and approved by the employee who extended the credit; and
Documented in the credit file.

A facility operator shall deposit a replacement check accepted from a player in a substitution, consolidation, or partial redemption transaction in its bank account or present the replacement check directly to the player’s bank:
On the deposit date of the initial counter check in accordance with Regulation .28D of this chapter; and
In accordance with one of the deposit options of §A of this regulation.
A facility operator shall deposit in its bank account or present directly to the player’s bank a personal check accepted in full redemption of a counter check on the next day.
A facility operator:

If there are a series of consolidation or redemption transactions with a player, may substitute a current counter check for the earliest dated counter check returned to the player in the first of the series of consolidation or redemption transactions; and

In computing the time periods in §§A, B, and C of this regulation, shall consider the last day of the period to be included unless it is a Saturday, Sunday, or a State or federal holiday, in which event the time period runs until the next banking day.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures and controls addressing the deposit of counter checks and replacement checks.
A facility operator’s internal controls shall include:
Procedures and controls addressing:
Release of a counter check or replacement check for presentment to a player’s bank to:
A principal employee of the facility operator; or
An attorney; and
Correction, prior to deposit or presentment or on redeposit of a returned check, of data entry errors in:
Bank name;
Bank routing number;
Bank account number; or
Micro-encoding number; and
A prohibition against correcting information that identifies the verified bank account on which the counter check was originally drawn.
All checks returned after deposit shall be:
Returned directly to an accounting department employee with no incompatible functions; and
Maintained by a check bank cashier with no incompatible functions.
A facility operator shall:
Limit collection efforts pertaining to a returned check to the following persons:
A gaming or principal licensed employee of the accounting department with no incompatible functions; and
An attorney representing the facility operator;
Notice the employee or attorney authorized to conduct collection efforts of any verbal or written communication with a player regarding collection efforts;
Document all collection efforts in the player’s credit file; and
Send a statement to a player at reasonable intervals.
After reasonable collection efforts, returned checks may be considered uncollectible for accounting purposes if the write off is authorized by the:
Chief executive officer; and
Director of finance or another designated principal employee who does not possess authority to authorize credit or approve a change in a credit limit.

section.heading: Accounting Controls in a Check Bank.

para.text: In addition to the documentation requirements of Regulations .24 and .25 of this chapter, a facility operator shall record in a player’s credit file all transactions affecting a player's outstanding indebtedness to the facility operator, and the credit file shall include:
Transactions recorded in chronological order;
Credit transactions segregated from customer deposit transactions; and
Documentation of:
For counter checks, the date, amount, and series number;
For each substitution check:
The date, amount, and check number of the substitute check; and
The series number of the counter check or check number of the replacement check returned to the player;
For each consolidation check:
The date, amount, and check number of the consolidation check; and
The series numbers of the counter check or check number of the replacement check returned to the player;
For each redemption check:
The date, amount, and check number of the redemption check;
An indication as to whether the redemption was partial or full; and
The series number of the counter check or check number of the replacement check returned to the player;
Date, amount, and series or check number of each check:
Deposited; and
Returned;
If a check has been returned, the reason for its return;
Player’s outstanding balance after each transaction;
Date, amount, and series or check number of a check which has been partially or completely written off by the facility operator; and
If a write off, the reason for the write off.
A facility operator shall maintain original copies of counter checks and replacement checks accepted in substitution, consolidation, and redemption transactions in its check bank.

A facility operator’s check bank shall prepare and maintain for each shift, manually or by computer, a log of all counter checks exchanged and of all replacement checks received in substitution, consolidation, and redemption transactions which includes the following:
The balance of the checks on hand in the check bank at the beginning of each shift;
For counter checks accepted and for replacement checks received in substitution, consolidation, or redemption on the shift:
Date of the check;
Name of the drawer of the check;
Amount of the check;
If a counter check, the series number;
If a replacement check, the check number; and
If applicable, an indication that the check was accepted in a substitution, consolidation, or redemption transaction;
For checks deposited, substituted, consolidated, or redeemed by a player on the shift:
Date on which the check was deposited, substituted, consolidated, or redeemed;
Name of the drawer of the check;
Amount of the check;
If a counter check, the series number;
If a replacement check, the check number; and
An indication as to whether the check was deposited, substituted, consolidated, or redeemed; and
The balance of the checks on hand in the check bank at the end of each shift.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing accounting controls over the check bank, including end of shift and end of gaming day deposits and reconciliations.

section.heading: Player Request for Suspension of Credit Privileges.

para.text: A player may voluntarily suspend the player’s credit privileges at a Maryland facility by submitting a written request to the facility in a form specified by the facility.
A request for suspension of credit privileges shall be made:
In person at a facility; or
By mail if:
Submitted with a signature signed before a notary public or other individual empowered by law to take oaths; and
Accompanied by a certificate of acknowledgement by the notary public or other individual empowered by law to take oaths attesting to the identity of the individual making the request.
The facility receiving a player’s request for suspension of credit privileges shall maintain a master list of all individuals who have requested suspension of credit privileges under this regulation.

A facility operator shall suspend the credit privileges of an individual requesting suspension within 24 hours of receipt of notice that the individual’s name has been added to the facility’s master list.
A facility operator shall:
Maintain the most current master list in its cashiers’ cage; and
Within 24 hours of receipt of notice that an individual has requested a suspension of credit privileges, record the suspension in the player’s credit file.

No less than 60 days after the request for suspension of credit privileges, a player whose credit privileges have been suspended under this regulation may request reinstatement of credit privileges by submitting a written request to the facility.
The facility shall on receipt of a request for reinstatement update its master list of individuals to document the request for reinstatement.
A facility operator may not reinstate the credit privileges of a player removed from facility’s master list without performing the verifications required by Regulation .25 of this chapter.

Information furnished to or obtained by the facility under this regulation shall be deemed confidential and may not be disclosed except to facility personnel whose duties and functions require access to the information.

A facility operator requested to provide information regarding the status of a player’s credit account may not disclose any information other than to identify the credit account as voluntarily suspended.

section.heading: Prohibition on the Use of Credit Cards and Debit Cards.
section.text: A video lottery terminal or table game may not be played or activated in any way by insertion, directly or indirectly, or use of a:

para.text: Credit card;
Debit card; or
Electronic transfer of funds from a credit card or debit card.

For the purposes of this regulation, a player tracking system means the collective hardware, software, communications technology, and other ancillary equipment owned or leased by a facility operator to collect, monitor, interpret, analyze, authorize, report, and audit data pertaining to:
Player activity generally at video lottery terminals and table games; and
Individual player activity at video lottery terminals and table games where the player has registered with the facility operator for inclusion in the player tracking system.
A facility operator shall utilize a player tracking system meeting the requirements of this subtitle.
A facility operator may not collect or monitor the activity of an individual who it knows, suspects, or has reason to know or suspect is:
Under the age of 21 years;
Mandatorily excluded in accordance with State Government Article, §9-1A-24(d), Annotated Code of Maryland; or
Voluntarily excluded in accordance State Government Article, §9-1A-24(e), Annotated Code of Maryland.
A facility operator shall provide a player with a record of video lottery terminal and table game spending levels if:
The player:
Has registered with the facility for inclusion in the player tracking system; and
Submits a signed request for the spending level documentation at:
The cashiers' cage; or
Other location at the facility approved by the Commission; and
The identification of the player and the authenticity of the player's signature on the request is established by an employee satisfactorily comparing the:

Player's information recorded on the spending level request documentation with the information contained on the valid, unexpired government-issued photographic identification presented by the player; and
Player's physical appearance with the photograph contained on the valid, unexpired government-issued photographic identification presented by the player.
A facility operator shall provide a player with a record of video lottery terminal and table game spending levels if the player:
Has registered online with the facility operator for the establishment of an account; and
Enters a unique login credential at a:
Self-service kiosk; or
Facility operator’s player rewards website.
A facility operator may issue a gaming ticket and utilize a gaming ticket system meeting the requirements of this subtitle.
A facility operator shall:
Issue a gaming ticket which does not expire for 182 days after the date of issuance;
Configure its gaming ticket system to:
Prevent issuance of a gaming ticket exceeding $10,000; and
Require gaming tickets of $5,000 or more to be redeemed only at the cashiers’ cage;
Configure a ticket redemption unit under Regulation .38 of this regulation to:
Redeem only a gaming ticket of less than $5,000; and
Direct a player attempting to redeem a gaming ticket of $5,000 or more to the cashiers’ cage; and
Redeem at its cashiers’ cage a gaming ticket of $5,000 or more by:
Cash or check; or
Check on the request of a player.

A facility operator shall immediately report to the Commission evidence that a gaming ticket has been counterfeited, tampered with, or altered in any way which would affect the integrity, fairness, or reliability of the gaming ticket.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing the issuance and redemption of a gaming ticket.
A facility operator’s internal controls shall:
Require a gaming ticket to include:
Name or trade name of the facility operator;
Date and time of issuance;
Amount of the gaming ticket;
Unique series number automatically generated by the gaming ticket system;
Asset number of the video lottery terminal dispensing the gaming ticket;
At least one anticounterfeiting measure, which appears on one or both sides of the gaming ticket;
Locations where the gaming ticket may be redeemed and any restrictions applicable to redemption;
A bar code or magnetic strip which enables the gaming ticket system to identify the numeric information required by this section; and
Notice to the player of the terms of expiration; and
Include procedures and controls which:
Require a gaming ticket system to perform the following prior to payment:
Verify the validity of the series number and amount of the gaming ticket; and
Electronically cancel the gaming ticket;
Require the gaming ticket system to be configured:

To permit access to the complete series number of an unredeemed gaming ticket only to gaming ticket system administrative employees and accounting department employees not assigned to the cashiers’ cage; and

To maintain a record of all unredeemed gaming tickets for a minimum of 2 years from the date of issuance of the gaming ticket unless a request to remove or relocate system records is submitted in writing and approved in writing by the Commission;
Address the following events:
Calculation and transmittal by the facility operator of its outstanding expired unredeemed gaming ticket balance to the State;
An election by a facility operator to pay a gaming ticket when the gaming ticket system is inoperable or otherwise unable to verify the validity of the gaming ticket at the time of payment; and

An election by a facility operator to pay a gaming ticket where the gaming ticket system fails to verify and electronically cancel the gaming ticket when it is presented by the player and scanned for verification; and
Require generation, at the conclusion of each gaming day, of reports detailing:
Gaming tickets issued;
Gaming tickets redeemed and cancelled by redemption location;
Unredeemed liability for gaming tickets;
Readings on gaming ticket related video lottery terminal meters;
Meter readings compared to number and amount of issued and redeemed gaming tickets; and
Any exceptions.
A facility operator may:
Issue promotional play if it is not awarded as cashable credit; and
Utilize a promotional play system meeting the requirements of this subtitle.
A facility operator may not issue to a player promotional play equaling or exceeding $5,000 per gaming day without approval from the chief executive or the chief executive’s designee.

A facility operator shall immediately report to the Commission evidence that a promotional play instrument has been counterfeited, tampered with, or altered in any way which would affect the integrity, fairness, or reliability of the promotional play instrument.
A facility operator shall submit to the Commission in a form and in accordance with a time frame specified by the Commission a quarterly report summarizing:
Promotional play awarded for the period including:
Total amount in promotional play awarded in noncashable credits; and
Other forms of promotional play; and
Promotional play redeemed by players for the period including:
Total amount in promotional play redeemed in noncashable credits; and
Other forms of promotional play redeemed.
A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing:
Methods utilized to:
Issue promotional play; and
Redeem promotional play; and
A promotion play instrument including a requirement that it document:
Name or trade name of the facility operator;
Amount in noncashable credits;
Unique series number automatically generated by the promotional play system;
Locations where a promotional instrument may be redeemed and any restrictions applicable to redemption;
A bar code or magnetic strip which enables the promotional play system to identify the numeric information required by this section; and
Notice to the player of the terms of expiration.
Limitation on Free Promotional Play.

Through the first full fiscal year of a facility’s operations, the proceeds of a facility excludes money given away by a licensee as free promotional play and used by players to bet in a video lottery terminal or at a table game.

After the first full fiscal year of a facility’s operations, the amount of money given away as free promotional play in a fiscal year may not exceed a percentage of the facility’s proceeds received in the prior fiscal year under State Government Article, §9-1A-27(a)(2), (c)(1)(ii), and (d)(1), Annotated Code of Maryland, that equates to 20 percent of total video lottery terminal and table game proceeds the facility generated in the prior fiscal year.

An amount of money given away as free promotional play in a fiscal year exceeding the percentage defined in §F(2) of this regulation of the facility’s proceeds of the prior fiscal year shall be allocated as proceeds under State Government Article, §9-1A-27, Annotated Code of Maryland.
No later than 90 days after the end of the fiscal year, a facility operator shall submit to the Commission a written:
Report of its use of free promotional play during the prior fiscal year; and
Recommendation for any adjustment to the limitation on free promotional play established under §F(2) of this regulation.
For purposes of §§F and G of this regulation, “fiscal year” means the fiscal year of the facility operator.
A facility operator may utilize a ticket redemption unit meeting the requirements of this subtitle.
A facility operator shall locate a ticket redemption unit on the gaming floor or cashier’s cage, subject to the surveillance coverage requirements of Regulation .11 of this chapter.
A ticket redemption unit:
Shall in accordance with Regulation .36 of this chapter be configured to:
Redeem a gaming ticket of less than $5,000; and
Direct a player attempting to redeem a gaming ticket of $5,000 or more to the cashiers’ cage; and
May be configured to function as a bill breaker changing bills of one denomination into bills of a smaller denomination.
A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted under Regulation .05 of this chapter, procedures addressing a ticket redemption unit.
A facility operator’s internal controls shall address:
Distribution of cash to a ticket redemption unit;
Removal of gaming tickets and cash accepted by a ticket redemption unit;
Reconciliations associated with the replenishment process;
Generation of the following reports by a ticket redemption unit or ancillary system or application for the reconciliation period, which may be by gaming day, shift, or drop cycle:
A gaming ticket transaction report which details:
Disposition, as paid, partially paid, or unpaid, of gaming tickets accepted by a ticket redemption unit;
Gaming ticket validation number;
Date and time of redemption;
Amount requested; and
Amount dispensed;
A reconciliation report which details:
Date and time;
Unique asset identification number of the ticket redemption unit;
Total amount of cash in the currency and coin cassettes;
Total number of bills accepted by denomination; and
Total amount of gaming tickets accepted; and
A gaming ticket and currency storage box report which details the following data whenever a storage box is removed from the ticket redemption unit:
Date and time;
Unique asset identification number of the ticket redemption unit;
Unique identification number for each storage box in the ticket redemption unit;
Total amount of currency dispensed;
Total number of bills dispensed by denomination;
Total amount of gaming tickets accepted;
Total count of gaming tickets accepted; and
Details required to be included in the gaming ticket transaction report required under §E(4)(a) of this regulation; and
A transaction history report which details all critical player transaction history including the date, time, amount, and disposition of each complete and incomplete transaction.
Definition.
A facility operator shall utilize a multipurpose jackpot or credit meter payout document meeting the requirements of this regulation to pay:
A jackpot not totally and automatically paid by a video lottery terminal; or
Credits accumulated by a player on a video lottery terminal if:
The number of accumulated credits exceeds the amount which may be paid utilizing a gaming ticket under Regulation .36 of this chapter;
Due to malfunction, the credits cannot be paid by the video lottery terminal; or
A single jackpot event requires the filing of IRS Form W-2G, Certain Gambling Winnings.
A facility operator shall:
Prepare and timely file IRS Form W-2G, Certain Gambling Winnings, in accordance with IRS rules and regulations;
Withhold payment of a jackpot prize to satisfy a player’s financial obligation to the State, such as the payment of child support arrearage or other requirements of State law; and
Immediately report to the Commission any incident in which a video lottery terminal fails to lock up and preclude play following a single jackpot event of $1,200 or more.
A facility operator shall pay a jackpot or credit meter payout of:
$50,000 or more by check; and
Less than $50,000 by:
Cash or check; or
On the request of a player, any combination of cash, gaming ticket, check, or other method of payment approved by the Commission.

A facility operator may withhold a player’s outstanding indebtedness to the facility from a jackpot prize or credit meter payout after satisfying a player’s financial obligation to the State, as required in §C(2) of this regulation;

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing the payment of a jackpot or credit meter payout not totally and automatically paid by a video lottery terminal.
A facility operator’s internal controls shall include:

The use of a two-part computer-generated jackpot or credit meter payout document initiated on the request of a gaming operations department attendant or gaming operations department supervisor or above after verifying the:
Winning combination of characters on the video lottery terminal or table game and the amount of the jackpot; or
Number of accumulated credits;

Unless a request for an alternate verification procedure is submitted in writing and approved by the Commission, a requirement that, if a jackpot or credit meter payout is $1,200 or more but less than $15,000, a security department employee or a gaming operations department attendant or gaming operations department supervisor or above other than the preparer of the document sign the jackpot or credit meter payout document after verifying the payment of the jackpot or credit meter payout to the player and:
Winning combination of characters on the video lottery terminal and the amount of the jackpot; or
Number of accumulated credits;
A provision that only the preparer is required to sign the jackpot or credit meter payout document if:
A jackpot or credit meter payout is less than $10,000;
A facility operator’s slot or casino management system can independently verify a jackpot or credit meter payout;
The facility operator’s slot or casino management system and the central monitor and control system are fully operational; and
Overrides or adjustments are not required;

A requirement that, if a jackpot or credit meter payout is $15,000 or more but less than $35,000, a security department employee or a gaming operations department supervisor or above other than the preparer of the document sign the jackpot or credit meter payout document after verifying the payment of the jackpot or credit meter payout to the player and:
Winning combination of characters on the video lottery terminal and the amount of the jackpot; or
Number of accumulated credits;

A provision that, if a jackpot or credit meter payout document generated under §G(1) of this regulation is requested by a gaming operations department supervisor or above, the verification required by §G(4) of this regulation may be completed by a gaming operations department attendant, a gaming operations department supervisor or above, or a security department employee;

A requirement that, if a jackpot or credit meter payout is $35,000 or more, an operations department shift manager or higher level operations department employee other than the preparer of the document sign the jackpot or credit meter payout document after verifying the payment of the jackpot or credit meter payout to the player and:
Winning combination of characters on the video lottery terminal and amount of the jackpot; or
Number of accumulated credits;

A provision that, if a jackpot or credit meter payout document required under §G(1) of this regulation is requested by a gaming operations department shift manager or higher level gaming operations department employee, the verification required by §G(6) of this regulation may be completed by a gaming operations department attendant, a gaming operations department supervisor or above, or a security department employee;
A requirement that the following information be on a two-part computer-generated jackpot or credit meter payout document:
Date and time;
Asset number of the video lottery terminal or table game on which the jackpot was registered or credits accumulated;

Winning combination of characters constituting the jackpot or a code corresponding to the winning combination of characters constituting the jackpot or an indication that a credit meter payout is to be made;
Amount to be paid;
Unique transaction number generated by the video lottery system;
Signature or identification code of the preparer of the document;
If the payout is $1,200 or more, the signature or identification code of a verifying witness in accordance with this regulation; and
Unless an automated jackpot payout machine or a cash wallet is utilized to effect the payment, the signature or identification code of the cashier issuing the funds;
If utilized, procedures and controls applicable to a jackpot or credit meter payout:
Using an automated jackpot payout machine meeting the requirements of Regulation .42 of this chapter; and
By a gaming operations department attendant from a cash wallet impressed with $10,000 or less;
If utilized, procedures and controls to be implemented if the facility operator resets the video lottery terminal or credit meter before the player is paid;
A requirement that the surveillance department:
Be notified of a jackpot or credit meter payout of $25,000 or more;
Log all notices regarding a jackpot or credit meter payout in the surveillance log required under Regulation .12 of this chapter; and
Obtain and retain in accordance with Regulation .11 of this chapter a photograph of the face of the player receiving the payout;
Details pertaining to:
Payment of a jackpot or credit meter payout at the:
Cashiers’ cage;
Video lottery terminal; and
Table game;
The use of an accounting drop box; and
Audit procedures to be performed by the facility operator’s accounting department at the conclusion of each gaming day;
Procedures addressing unclaimed jackpots or accumulated credits abandoned on a video lottery terminal or table game;
Details which establish the ability of the facility operator’s video lottery system to:
Ensure that a two-part computer-generated jackpot or credit meter payout document is not susceptible to change or deletion from the system after preparation;
Process and document system overrides or adjustments to jackpot or credit meter payouts including:
Overrides or adjustments where the payout requested does not match the payout amount sent from the video lottery terminal to the video lottery system; and
Identification of the level of employee having override authority; and
Process voided jackpot or credit meter payout documents; and
Procedures utilized to issue a manual jackpot or credit meter payout document which:
Are to be used only when the video lottery system is unable to generate an jackpot or credit meter payout document;
Conform to the jackpot payout or credit meter payout verification and signature requirements of this regulation;
Involve use of a three-part serially prenumbered manual jackpot or credit meter payout document residing in a book, wiz machine, or functional equivalent;
Require manual jackpot or credit meter payout books or their functional equivalent to be maintained in a secured locked cabinet in the cashiers’ cage; and
Require the key to the cabinet in §G(15)(d) of this regulation to be:
Controlled by the security department or the accounting department; and
Limited to sign out by a gaming operations department supervisor or above.
Definitions.
In this regulation, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Annuity jackpot” means a video lottery terminal or table game jackpot in which a player wins the right to receive fixed cash payments at specified intervals; and

“Discount rate” means a discount rate equal to the United States Treasury constant maturity rate for 20-year United States government securities for the week ending prior to the date of the jackpot, as identified in the applicable H.15 Statistical Release issued by the Federal Reserve Board plus 0.5 percent.
A facility operator may not offer an annuity jackpot without the prior written approval of the Commission.
A facility operator submitting a request for approval of an annuity jackpot to the Commission shall submit details pertaining to the annuity jackpot including:
The specific terms of:
The annuity; and
Any cash payout option;
The written trust agreement supporting the trust fund used to make future cash payments on the annuity jackpot, including details pertaining to:
Administration and funding of the trust agreement;
Liability for payments owed to a player; and
Designation of a trustee;
Internal controls addressing the offer and award of an annuity jackpot in accordance with §G of this regulation; and
Documentation supporting that the average payout percentage on the video lottery terminal offering the annuity jackpot will comply with this subtitle.

A facility operator that offers an annuity jackpot payable over 10 years or more may offer a player the option to be paid in a single cash payout provided that payout is equal to the present value of the annuity jackpot as calculated in §E of this regulation.
The present value of a cash payout option on an annuity jackpot shall be determined by:
Applying the discount rate to each of the future annuity jackpot payments;
Multiplying the number of years until each jackpot payment would otherwise have been received; and
Adding to that amount the amount of the first cash payment that would otherwise have been received.
A facility operator shall pay a cash payout requested by a player in lieu of an annuity jackpot in accordance with Regulation .39 of this chapter.
A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing the offer and award of an annuity jackpot.
A facility operator’s internal controls shall include:
Procedures to be followed by a player to exercise a cash payout option; and
Procedures utilized to document payment of an annuity jackpot.
Definitions.
In this regulation, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Merchandise” means goods, commodities, or other things of value; and
“Merchandise jackpot” means a video lottery terminal or table game jackpot in which a player wins:
Merchandise;
A combination of a cash payout and merchandise; or
An option to choose between a cash payout and merchandise.
A facility operator may not offer a merchandise jackpot without the prior written approval of the Commission.
A facility operator submitting a request for approval of a merchandise jackpot to the Commission shall submit details pertaining to the merchandise jackpot including:
The specific terms of:
The merchandise offer; and
Any cash payout option;
Documentation supporting the acquisition of the merchandise and its cash equivalent value under §D of this regulation;
Internal controls addressing the offer and award of a merchandise jackpot in accordance with §H of this regulation; and
Documentation supporting that the average payout percentage on the video lottery terminal offering the merchandise jackpot will comply with this subtitle.

If a facility operator offers a merchandise jackpot consisting of merchandise or an optional cash payout, the optional cash payout shall equal the cash equivalent value of the merchandise determined in accordance with §E of this regulation.
The cash equivalent value of merchandise shall be determined as follows:
Merchandise that the facility operator sells directly to the public in the normal course of business shall be valued at an amount equal to the full retail price normally charged for the merchandise;

Merchandise that the facility operator does not sell directly to the public in the normal course of business, but which is provided directly to a player by the facility operator, shall be valued at an amount equal to the actual cost to the facility operator of the merchandise;

Merchandise that is provided directly or indirectly to a player on behalf of a facility operator by a third party not related to the facility operator shall be valued at an amount equal to the actual cost to the facility operator of having the third party provide the merchandise; and

Merchandise that is provided directly or indirectly to a player on behalf of a facility operator by a third party who is related to the facility operator shall be valued as if the related party were the facility operator under §E(1) and (2) of this regulation.
For the purpose of determining proceeds, the cash equivalent value of any merchandise paid as, or as a portion of, a jackpot shall be included in total winnings paid.

A facility operator shall pay a cash payout portion of a merchandise jackpot and a cash payout requested by a player in lieu of a merchandise jackpot in accordance with Regulation .39 of this chapter.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing the offer and award of a merchandise jackpot.
A facility operator’s internal controls shall include:
Procedures to be followed by a player to exercise a cash payout option; and
Procedures utilized to document payment of a merchandise jackpot.
A facility operator may utilize an automated jackpot payout machine meeting the requirements of this subtitle.
A facility operator may locate an automated jackpot payout machine on the gaming floor subject to the surveillance coverage requirements of Regulation .11 of this chapter.
A facility operator shall, in accordance with Regulation .38D of this chapter, configure an automated jackpot payout machine to only process a jackpot or credit meter payout of less than $50,000.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing the payment of a jackpot or credit meter payout utilizing an automated jackpot payout machine.
A facility operator’s internal controls shall include procedures and controls documenting:
A jackpot or credit meter payout transaction at an automated jackpot payout machine; and
Reconciliation and replenishment of an automated jackpot payout machine.

section.heading: Access to Bill Validators, Cash Storage, and Table Game Drop Boxes.

para.text: Access.
A facility operator shall control access to a bill validator, a cash storage box housed in a video lottery terminal, and a table game drop box in accordance with this regulation.
Access to a bill validator shall be controlled by:
At least one lock; and
Requiring the key to the lock to be maintained by the security department.

The cash storage box shall be secured to a bill validator by two separate locks, the keys to which are different from each other, and, for the lock on the belly door or main door of the video lottery terminal:
The key shall be controlled by the slots department in:
A manual key box; or
An automated key tracking system;
Immediately prior to the commencement of the drop, the slots department may issue its belly door or main door key to the accounting department;
A key transferred from the slots department to the accounting department shall be returned immediately following the conclusion of the drop;
The facility operator shall establish sign in and sign out procedures in its internal controls documenting the transfers; and
If an automated key tracking system is used, a facility operator shall require dual access from the security department and accounting department to obtain keys.
The lock on the release mechanism securing the cash storage box to the bill validator shall be controlled by the security department.
Access to the contents of a cash storage box shall be controlled by:
At least one lock; and
Requiring the key to the lock to be maintained by the accounting department.
Control. A facility operator shall either:
Assign to a cash storage box an asset number that:
Is permanently imprinted or affixed to the outside of the cash storage box; and
Corresponds to the asset number of the video lottery terminal in which the cash storage box is installed; or
With the written approval of the Commission, utilize a computerized system for:
Assigning a unique identification number to a cash storage box; and
Attributing it to the video lottery terminal in which the cash storage box is installed.
Unique identification number. A facility operator shall ensure that an asset number or unique identification number on a cash storage box is clearly visible to:
An employee involved in removing or replacing a cash storage box; and
The surveillance department.
Emergency cash storage box. A facility operator may maintain an emergency cash storage box without an asset number or a unique identification number if:
The word "emergency" is permanently imprinted or affixed on the box; and
When put into use, the cash storage box is temporarily marked with the asset number of the video lottery terminal in which it is installed.
Table Game Drop Box.
A table game shall have a secure tamper-resistant table game drop box attached to it in which the following shall be deposited:
Cash exchanged for gaming chips and plaques at the gaming table;
Issuance copies of counter checks exchanged at the gaming table for gaming chips and plaques;
Copies of fill request slips, fill slips, credit request slips, credit slips, and table inventory slips; and
Other table game wagering instruments approved by the Commission.
A table game drop box shall have:
One lock securing the contents deposited into it;
A separate lock securing the table game drop box to the gaming table, the key to which must be different from the keys to the locks securing the contents of the table game drop box;

A slot opening through which currency, value chips, or poker rake chips for nonbanking games, other table game wagering instruments approved by the Commission, and required instruments can be inserted into it;
A mechanical device that automatically closes and locks the slot opening upon removal of the table game drop box from the gaming table; and
Permanently imprinted or impressed thereon, and clearly visible to surveillance, either:
A number corresponding to a unique permanent number on the gaming table to which the table game drop box is attached and at least one letter indicating the type of game; and
The word “emergency”.
In addition to the requirements of §E(2)(e) of this regulation, a table game drop box may also be identified by a bar code label that is securely affixed to the table game drop box and shall be:
At a minimum, encoded with the information required under §E(2)(e) of this regulation; and
Prepared in accordance with the facility operator’s approved internal controls.
The security department shall control the key used to release a table game drop box from a table game in a manual key box or an automated key tracking system.

Immediately prior to the commencement of the table game count process, the security department may issue its release key to the count room supervisor for the purpose of resetting the release mechanism on empty table game drop boxes;
A key transferred by the security department shall be immediately returned after the conclusion of the table game drop box count;
In its internal controls, a facility operator shall establish sign-in and sign-out procedures governing key transfers and control of a key during breaks taken by count room personnel; and
