If an automated key tracking system is used, a facility operator shall require dual access from the security department and accounting department to obtain keys.
The keys to the table game drop box locks required under §E(2)(a) of this regulation shall be controlled by the accounting department.
Before using a table game drop box labeled “Emergency” for a table game, a facility manager shall:
Obtain verbal approval of Commission compliance personnel; and
Temporarily mark the emergency table game drop box with the number of the gaming table and at least one letter indicating the game type.

section.heading: Collection of Cash Storage and Table Game Drop Boxes.

para.text: At least 30 days before video lottery terminal or table game operations are to commence, a facility operator shall submit to the Commission in writing a drop schedule setting forth:
Specific pick-up days and times for collection of cash storage and table game drop boxes and requirements that:
Cash storage boxes may not be commingled with table game drop boxes;
Unless a drop box is from a table game pit that was never opened for gaming on that gaming day, table game drop boxes shall be collected once each gaming day; and
The facility operator notify the Commission by telephone and in writing 1 hour in advance of changes to the table game drop box collection schedule required under §A(1)(b) of this regulation.
Specifications as to what areas of the gaming floor will be covered on each pick-up day; and
Specific transportation routes to be utilized from the gaming floor to the count room on each pick-up day.
A facility operator shall notify the Commission:
In writing, of a permanent change in the drop schedule including a pick-up day or time, area of the floor to be dropped, or transportation route; and
Prior to any temporary deviation from the drop schedule.
A facility operator shall make readily available to the Commission:
An access control matrix indicating which employee job descriptions are authorized to participate in the cash storage and table game drop box collection process; and
A list of employees, with license numbers, who are authorized to participate in the cash storage and table game drop box collection process.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing the collection of cash storage and table game drop boxes.
A facility operator’s internal controls shall:
Detail the actual procedures to be performed and documentation to be generated by drop team employees collecting cash storage and table game drop boxes:
In accordance with the drop schedule; and
On an emergency basis; and
Require:
Cash storage and table game drop boxes to be transported directly to, and secured in:
The count room; or
A trolley storage area approved by the Commission under COMAR 36.03.11;
The cash storage and table game drop box collection process to involve the participation of at least three employees, at least one of whom is an employee of the:
Security department; and
Accounting department;

Prior to the movement of a trolley containing cash storage boxes from the gaming floor into the count room, an accounting department supervisor to verify that the number of cash storage boxes being transported from the gaming floor equals the number of cash storage boxes scheduled for collection that day;

Prior to the movement of a trolley containing table game drop boxes from the gaming floor into the count room, an accounting department supervisor or floorperson or above to verify that the number of table game drop boxes being transported from the gaming floor equals the number of table game drop boxes scheduled for collection; and
Prior to changing the type of table game offered, or removing a video lottery terminal or table game from the gaming floor, that an emergency drop shall be conducted.
A facility operator shall transport cash storage and table game drop boxes in an enclosed trolley secured by one lock that has a key which is controlled by the security department.
A facility operator shall store cash storage and table game drop boxes not attached to a bill validator, including emergency cash storage and table game drop boxes that are not actively in use:
In the count room in an area approved by the Commission;
In a trolley storage area approved by the Commission under COMAR 36.03.11; or
In another location at the facility approved by the Commission.
The cabinet or trolley used for storage under §G of this regulation shall be secured by one lock that has a key which is controlled by the security department in:
A manual key box; or
An automated key tracking system.

Immediately prior to the commencement of the count process, the security department may issue its key to the storage cabinet or trolley required under §G of this regulation to a count room supervisor for the purpose of allowing count room personnel to gain access to the cash storage or table game drop boxes to be counted.
A trolley storage area utilized to store cash storage or table game drop boxes prior to the count process shall meet the design standards for a count room under Regulation .44 of this chapter.
A facility operator shall have a count room designated, designed, and used for counting the contents of cash storage and table game drop boxes at a location approved by the Commission.
A count room shall conform to the following standards:
Be constructed of materials and have an interior design which provides maximum security over the assets stored, and the activities conducted in, the room;
Meet the surveillance requirements of Regulation .11 of this chapter including audio coverage of the count process; and
Be constructed with doors equipped with:
An alarm system which tracks all ingress to and egress from the room and:
Directly alerts the security department; or
Directly, or through a documented communications protocol, alerts the surveillance department; and
A locking mechanism with key backup, or a key that is:
Different from the key to any other door to the count room;
Different from the keys to the locks securing each cash storage and table game drop box; and
Controlled by the security department or the accounting department.

A facility operator shall install in its count room a table constructed of clear glass or similar transparent material to be used for the emptying, counting, and recording of the contents of cash storage and table game drop boxes.

section.heading: Accounting Controls for a Count Room.

para.text: Count Schedule. At least 30 days before video lottery terminal or table game operations are to commence, a facility operator shall submit to the Commission a count schedule setting forth the specific times during which cash storage and table game drop boxes are to be counted and recorded.
Notifications. A facility operator shall:
Notify the Commission in writing of any permanent change in the count schedule; and
Notify the Commission of any temporary deviation from the count schedule.
Count Frequency.

A facility operator shall count the contents of each cash storage box at least once every 7 days unless an alternative count schedule is submitted in writing to and approved in writing by the Commission.

A facility operator shall count the contents of each table game drop box at least once each gaming day unless an alternative count schedule is submitted to, and approved in writing by, the Commission.
Unless no gaming is conducted or otherwise offered at the video lottery facility, a facility operator shall count the contents of each table game drop box at least once each gaming day.
The following shall be counted and recorded separately:
Table game drop boxes from banking games; and
Table game drop boxes from nonbanking games.

Procedures. A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved by the Commission under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures addressing the counting and recording of cash storage and table game drop boxes.
Internal Controls. A facility operator’s internal controls shall:
Detail all hardware, software, and related equipment utilized by the facility operator to conduct the count;
Detail the actual procedures to be performed and documentation to be generated by:
Count team employees conducting the counting process; and
The main bank cashier in verifying and accepting the count;
Require computerized equipment utilized to count and strap currency, gaming tickets, and promotional play instruments to:
Conduct two separate counts;
If the separate counts are not in agreement, document the discrepancy;
Be capable of determining the amount of a gaming ticket or promotional play instrument by independently examining information printed on the gaming ticket or promotional play instrument and:
Calculating the amount internally; or
Obtaining the amount directly from a gaming ticket system or promotional play system in a secure manner; and

If a gaming ticket system or promotional play system is utilized to obtain the amount of a gaming ticket or promotional play instrument, require the system to perform a calculation or integrity check to ensure that the amount of the gaming ticket or promotional play instrument has not been altered in the system in any manner since the time of issuance;
Require a count room employee to:
Wear a one-piece, pocketless garment;
Carry only a handbag or other container constructed of transparent material; and

Remove the count room employee’s hands from, or return them to, a position on or above the count table or counting equipment only after holding the backs and palms of the hands straight out and exposing them to the view of other employees of the count team and a surveillance camera; and
Prior to the commencement of the count, require a count room employee to notify the surveillance department and receive confirmation that recording of the count process has commenced.
Table Game Drop Box Count Requirements.
The Commission may require that the table game drop box be conducted in the presence of a Commission compliance representative.

After the contents of each table game drop box from a banking table game are counted, a member of the count team shall record, on a three-part Daily Banking Table Game Count Report or electronic equivalent prepared on a computer system, the following:
Value of each denomination of currency counted;
Total value of all denominations of currency counted;
Gaming date of the items being recorded;
Total number of banking table game drop boxes opened and counted; and
Current date.

After the contents of each table game drop box from a nonbanking table game are counted, a member of the count team shall record the following on a three-part Daily Nonbanking Table Game Count Report or electronic equivalent prepared on a computer system:
Value of poker rake chips counted;
Value of value chips counted;
Total value of poker rake chips and value chips counted;
Gaming date of the items being recorded;
Total number of nonbanking table game drop boxes opened and counted; and
Current date.

After the preparation of the Daily Banking Table Game Count Report and the Daily Nonbanking Table Game Count Report, the count team members and the count room supervisor shall sign the reports attesting to the accuracy of the information recorded thereon.

After the contents of all table game drop boxes have been counted, all cash, value chips, and poker rake chips shall be presented in the count room by a count team member to a main bank cashier or cage supervisor who, prior to having access to the information recorded on the Daily Banking Table Game Count Report and Daily Nonbanking Table Game Count Report, and in the presence of the count team members and, if required, a Commission compliance representative, shall recount the currency, value chips, and poker rake chips as follows:
The main bank cashier or cage supervisor may bulk count all strapped currency;
The Commission compliance representative may direct that currency straps be recounted by the main bank cashier or cage supervisor if a discrepancy is discovered during the initial bulk recount; and
All partial straps, loose currency, mutilated or torn currency, value chips, and poker rake chips shall be recounted by the main bank cashier or cage supervisor.

Upon completion of the recount, the main bank cashier or cage supervisor shall attest to the accuracy of the count by signature on the Daily Banking Table Game Count Report and Daily Nonbanking Table Game Count Report.
The Daily Banking Table Game Count Report and the Daily Nonbanking Table Game Count Report shall be distributed as follows:
Immediately after leaving the count room, the count room supervisor shall deliver the original to revenue audit or place it in a secure locked box controlled by revenue audit;
The Commission compliance representative who observed the count shall retain the second copy; and
The cage supervisor or main bank cashier shall retain the third copy.

Immediately after leaving the count room, the count room supervisor shall deliver any additional documents contained in the table game drop boxes to revenue audit or place the documents in a secured locked box controlled by revenue audit, including:
Requests for fills;
Fill slips;
Requests for credit;
Credit slips;
Issuance copies of counter checks; and
Table inventory slips.

A count room employee shall conduct a thorough inspection of the count room, and all counting equipment in the count room, to verify that no currency, chips, checks, vouchers, coupons, or other documentation remains in the room.

A gaming ticket or promotional play instrument accepted by a cash storage or table game drop box shall be counted and included in the calculation of proceeds without regard to the validity of the gaming ticket or promotional play instrument.
A promotional play instrument which is not cancelled upon acceptance or during the count process shall be cancelled prior to the conclusion of the count.
A facility operator shall report in writing to the Commission within 72 hours of the count:

Any variance between the actual count of cash, gaming tickets, and promotional play instruments in a cash storage box as determined in the count room and the amount for that particular cash storage box recorded on the:
Facility operator’s video lottery terminal; and
If the data has been made available to the facility operator, the central monitor and control system;
The reason for the variance; and
Corrective action taken or adjustments made.

A facility operator shall construct all signs required under this regulation using a color scheme and font size reasonably expected to produce a sign which is readily visible to and readable by an individual entering the facility.

A facility operator shall post signs containing the following messages in a conspicuous location not more than 20 feet from each customer entrance to the facility: “An individual, including an off-duty officer or agent of a local, state or federal law enforcement agency, may not possess a weapon or other device designed to be used to inflict pain or cause injury in (name of facility) without the prior written approval of the Maryland State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission.”
A facility operator shall attempt to timely resolve a dispute with a player concerning operation of a video lottery terminal, table game, or payment of alleged winnings.
A facility operator who is unable to satisfactorily resolve a dispute with a player within 3 days of notice of the dispute shall notify the Commission of the dispute.

On receipt of notice by the facility operator of the dispute, the Commission shall provide the player with a Commission player complaint form together with instructions for completing and submitting the form.
The Commission shall investigate a complaint submitted to the Commission and notify the player and facility operator of its determination.
The Commission may provide a player with a complaint form at any time upon request.

section.heading: Possession of a Weapon in a Facility.

para.text: Except as otherwise provided in this regulation, an individual may not possess in a facility:
A firearm as defined in Public Safety Article, §5-101, Annotated Code of Maryland;
An electronic control device as defined in Criminal Law Article, §4-109, Annotated Code of Maryland;
A dangerous weapon as defined in Criminal Law Article, §4-101, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
Any other device or object designed to be used to inflict pain or cause injury.
The prohibition in §A of this regulation:
Applies to all employees and contractors of the facility operator including security department employees; and
Does not apply to:
An on-duty officer or agent of a local, State or federal law enforcement agency having proper jurisdiction over the facility when the officer or agent is acting in an official capacity;
An individual who is employed by an armored car company or other entity that is under contract with the facility to transport cash or a cash equivalent; or
An individual authorized by the Commission to possess a weapon or device identified in §A of this regulation.
An individual requesting Commission authorization to possess a weapon identified in §A of this regulation in a facility shall submit to the Commission in writing a request documenting:
A compelling need to possess a weapon in the facility;
That the individual is lawfully in possession of the weapon under applicable federal and State law; and
That the individual has received training in the possession and use of the weapon.
Except as otherwise provided in this regulation:
A supervisory video lottery employee of a facility is prohibited from soliciting or accepting a tip or gratuity directly from a player;
A video lottery employee is prohibited from soliciting a tip or gratuity from a player; and
A facility operator may permit an employee who is authorized to accept a gratuity from a player to accept a gaming ticket if the gaming ticket is redeemed:
At the cashiers’ cage; and
With approval of the employee’s department supervisor, if the amount of the gaming ticket exceeds $100.

At least 30 days before table game operations are to commence, a facility operator shall submit to the Commission for approval internal controls relating to the acceptance of tips or gratuities by dealers at banking and nonbanking table games.
Except as provided in §G of this regulation, a dealer shall immediately deposit all tips and gratuities into a transparent locked box reserved for tips and gratuities, and:

If roulette chips are received as a tips or gratuity, the marker button indicating the specific value of the roulette chips may not be removed until after the dealer, in the presence of a floorperson or above, has converted the roulette chips into value chips which shall then be immediately deposited in the transparent locked box reserved for tips and gratuities;
Tip and gratuities shall be:
Collected and accounted for at least once each gaming day; and
Placed in a common pool for distribution pro rata among all dealers in accordance with §E of this regulation; and
A facility operator may include dealer supervisors in the common pool described in §C(3) of this regulation.
Upon receipt of a tip or gratuity from a player, the dealer shall extend the dealer’s arm in an overt motion and deposit the tip or gratuity in the locked box reserved for tips and gratuities.

Tips and gratuities placed in a common pool shall be distributed pro rata among the dealers in the pool based on the number of hours worked and based on any standards for distribution established by a facility operator, which may include:
Hours of vacation time, personal leave time, or any other authorized leave of absence in the number of hours worked by each employee; and
Different full-time or part-time employees.
A distribution of tips and gratuities from a common tip pool shall occur no more than once every 7 calendar days.
Notwithstanding the requirements in §C of this regulation, a facility operator that offers the game of poker:
May establish a separate common pool for tips and gratuities received by its poker dealers; or
If it allows a poker dealer to retain the poker dealer’s own tips and gratuities:
Shall require tips and gratuities received by a poker dealer to be deposited in a transparent locked box assigned to the particular dealer; and
Shall require that the transparent locked box be moved from table to table with the dealer.
If a facility operator elects to follow the requirements of §G(2) of this regulation, at the end of the poker dealer's shift:
The dealer shall take the transparent locked box assigned to the dealer to a cage cashier; and
The cage cashier shall open the container and count the tips and gratuities in the presence of the poker dealer, and record the total amount of the tips and gratuities received by the dealer, and:
Return the tips and gratuities to the dealer; or
Retain all or a portion of the tips and gratuities for inclusion in the dealer's paycheck.
If a facility operator elects to follow the requirements of §G(2) of this regulation and has established a gaming industry tip and compliance agreement, §H of this regulation does not apply.
A facility operator shall specify in its internal controls how dealer tips and gratuities will be reported to the Internal Revenue Service.
A facility operator may establish an off-site customer service location for a player to:
Establish a customer deposit account and make a deposit under Regulation .23 of this chapter; and
Pay a counter check under Regulation .28 of this chapter.
A facility operator that uses an off-site customer service location shall have internal controls that require:
Establishment of a compliance program required under COMAR 36.03.10.07.Q, that is updated to include the off-site customer service location operation;
Identification of the:
Address of the off-site customer service location;
Date the off-site customer service location is expected to open;
Name and contact information of the off-site customer service location manager;
Off-site customer service location telephone number(s);
Off-site customer service location normal hours of operation; and
An organization chart listing all positions that will have responsibility over Maryland operations related to the off-site customer service location;
Commencement of an off-site customer service location operation only after receiving Commission approval;

An employee independent of the off-site customer service location operation and the cage department to submit a monthly listing and reconciliation of all outstanding credit instruments that have been transferred to branch offices to the credit issuances and payments recorded by the cage;
An Off-Site Customer Service Location Report to be maintained by the licensee and updated quarterly to include the following for each off-site customer service location:
Address and telephone numbers;
If applicable, opening and closing date;
Name of the off-site customer service location manager;
Off-site customer service location normal hours of operation; and
Year-to-date and previous calendar year dollar amounts of the following Maryland specific transactions received or disbursed, and controlled by, the off-site customer service location:
Cash deposits, noncash deposits, and total deposits;
Cash withdrawals, noncash withdrawals, and total withdrawals; and
Cash payments on credit instruments, noncash payments on credit instruments, and total payments on credit instruments;
The Off-Site Customer Service Location Report to be submitted to the Commission no later than 30 days after the end of the calendar year;
An off-site customer service location to maintain the following records for Maryland video lottery operations:
A separate monthly log, by day, of payments received on credit instruments that includes:
Player’s name on an account to which a payment is being applied;
Name of individual making a payment;
Date of payment;
Amount of payment; and
Whether a payment was by cash, check or other financial instrument;
A separate monthly log, by day, of all funds deposited and withdrawn that includes:
Player’s name on an account to which the funds are being applied;
Name of the individual making the payment;
Date of deposit or withdrawal;
Amount of deposit or withdrawal;
Whether the transfer of funds was made by cash, check, or other financial instrument; and
New ending account balance; and
Monthly record of currency exchange rate gains and losses and money changer fees in conjunction with a player’s payment on a credit instrument that includes:
Player’s name;
Date of receipt; and
Amount of payment; and
Any costs associated with the Commission’s audit or review of an off-site customer service location operation to be reimbursed by the licensee to the Commission.
An off-site customer service location may not open until the Commission approves:
The internal controls described in §B of this regulation; and
An activation request submitted by the facility to the Commission.

section.heading: Donation of Coins from Gaming Payouts.

para.text: A facility operator shall offer players the opportunity to donate to the Maryland Veterans Trust Fund by providing at least one donation box or container that is:
Clearly marked as accepting donations for the Maryland Veterans Trust Fund;
Equipped with an opening that is large enough for players to donate coins, cash, gaming chips, gaming tickets, or other items that are redeemable for cash at the facility;
Capable of being locked;
Securely attached to a stationary object or otherwise secured to prevent unauthorized removal of the box or container; and
Located near an exit, cage, customer service window or kiosk, or in any other part of the facility that experiences high player traffic.

A facility operator shall develop and include in the internal controls submitted to and approved under Regulation .05 of this chapter procedures and controls addressing the donation and security of items described in §A(2) of this regulation as donations to the Maryland Veterans Trust Fund.

An item that was deposited into a Maryland Veterans Trust Fund box or container described in §A of this regulation may not be distributed as an unclaimed video lottery terminal jackpot under COMAR 36.03.01.03.
